para.inline: 40F Minister to have regard to certain matters

subdebate.1.para: (1) In deciding whether to approve a draft digital data service plan for a general digital data service area, the Minister must have regard to whether:
(a) the plan provides for the general digital data service obligation (in so far as it relates to that area) to be fulfilled:
(i) as efficiently and economically as practicable; and
(ii) at performance standards that reasonably meet the social, industrial and commercial needs of the Australian community; and
(iii) progressively throughout that area within such period as the Minister considers reasonable; and
(b) the draft plan complies with any requirements in force under section 40G.
(2) Subsection (1) does not, by implication, limit the matters to which regard may be had.
(3) In deciding whether to approve a draft digital data service plan for a special digital data service area, the Minister must have regard to whether:
(a) the plan provides for the special digital data service obligation (in so far as it relates to that area) to be fulfilled:
(i) as efficiently and economically as practicable; and
(ii) at performance standards that reasonably meet the social, industrial and commercial needs of the Australian community; and
(iii) progressively throughout that area within such period as the Minister considers reasonable; and
(b) the draft plan complies with any requirements in force under section 40G.
(4) Subsection (3) does not, by implication, limit the matters to which regard may be had.

para.inline: 40G Minister may formulate requirements for draft plans

subdebate.1.para: (1) The Minister may, by writing, formulate requirements to be complied with by draft digital data service plans.
(2) The following are examples of requirements:
(a) timetables for the supply of services;
(b) performance standards relating to the fulfilment of the digital data service obligation;
(c) the form of a draft digital data service plan.
(3) An instrument under subsection (1) is a disallowable instrument for the purposes of section 46A of the Acts Interpretation Act 1901.
(1) After deciding whether to approve a draft digital data service plan for an area, the Minister must give a written notice setting out the decision to:
(a) the digital data service provider concerned; and
(b) the ACA.
(2) A copy of a notice under subsection (1) must be published in the Gazette .

(3) If the Minister refuses to approve a draft digital data service plan for an area, the Minister must give a written notice setting out the reasons for the refusal to the digital data service provider concerned.

para.inline: 40J Variation of approved digital data service plan

subdebate.1.para: (1) This section applies if:
(a) an approved digital data service plan for an area (the current plan ) is in force; and
(b) the digital data service provider concerned gives the Minister a draft variation of the plan.
(2) The Minister must:
(a) approve the variation; or
(b) refuse to approve the variation.

(3) The Minister must not approve the variation unless the Minister is satisfied that, if it were assumed that the digital data service provider were to give the Minister a draft digital data service plan in the same terms as the current plan (as proposed to be varied), the Minister would approve that draft plan.
(4) After deciding whether to approve the variation, the Minister must give a written notice setting out the decision to:
(a) the digital data service provider concerned; and
(b) the ACA.
(5) A copy of a notice under subsection (4) must be published in the Gazette .
(6) If the Minister refuses to approve the variation, the Minister must give a written notice setting out the reasons for the refusal to the digital data service provider concerned.
(7) If the Minister approves the variation, the current plan is varied accordingly.
(1) Before giving the Minister a draft variation of a plan under section 40J, a digital data service provider must:
(a) publish a preliminary version of the draft variation and invite members of the public to make submissions to the provider about the preliminary version within a specified period; and
(b) give consideration to any submissions received from members of the public within that period.
(2) The period specified in the invitation must run for at least 30 days.
(3) This section does not apply to a draft variation given to the Minister in accordance with a notice under section 40M.

para.inline: 40L Minister may direct the ACA to give reports and/or advice

subdebate.1.para: (1) Before deciding whether to approve a draft digital data service plan or a draft variation of an approved digital data service plan, the Minister may direct the ACA to give the Minister such reports and/or advice as the Minister requires to assist in making the decision.
(2) The ACA must comply with the direction.
(3) This section does not, by implication, limit the Minister's powers under section 486 of the Telecommunications Act 1997 (which deals with public inquiries).

para.inline: 40M Minister may direct variation or replacement of plan

subdebate.1.para: (1) This section applies if an approved digital data service plan (the current plan ) for an area is in force.
(2) The Minister may give the digital data service provider concerned a written notice requiring the provider:
(a) within the period and in the terms set out in the notice, to give the Minister a draft variation of the current plan; or
(b) within the period and in the terms set out in the notice, to give the Minister a fresh draft digital data service plan for the area that is expressed to replace the current plan.
(3) The provider must comply with the notice.

para.inline: 40N Compliance with approved digital data service plan

subdebate.1.para: (1) If an approved digital data service plan for a general digital data service area is in force, the general digital data service provider concerned must take all reasonable steps to ensure that the plan is complied with.

(2) If an approved digital data service plan for a special digital data service area is in force, the special digital data service provider concerned must take all reasonable steps to ensure that the plan is complied with.

para.inline: 40P Register of digital data service plans

subdebate.1.para: (1) The ACA is to maintain a Register in which the ACA includes all approved digital data service plans currently in force.
(2) The Register may be maintained by electronic means.
(3) A person may, on payment of the charge (if any) fixed by a determination under section 53 of the Australian Communications Authority Act 1997 :
(a) inspect the Register; and
(b) make a copy of, or take extracts from, the Register.

(4) For the purposes of this section, if the Register is maintained by electronic means, a person is taken to have made a copy of, or taken an extract from, the Register if the ACA gives the person a printout of, or of the relevant parts of, the Register.
(5) If a person requests that a copy be provided in an electronic form, the ACA may provide the relevant information:
(a) on a data processing device; or
(b) by way of electronic transmission.

para.inline: 61A Digital data cost of a digital data service provider for a financial year

subdebate.1.para: (1) A person's digital data cost for a financial year depends on which of the following paragraphs is applicable for that financial year:
(a) if:
(i) the person is a digital data service provider in relation to that financial year because of the operation of a selection system determined under section 26C or 26D; and
(ii) the person has elected that a specified amount will be the person's digital data cost for the financial year;
the person's digital data cost for the financial year is equal to that amount;
(b) if:
(i) the person is a digital data service provider in relation to that financial year because of the operation of a selection system determined under section 26C or 26D; and
(ii) the person has elected that a specified method of ascertaining an amount will apply for the purposes of determining the person's digital data cost for the financial year;
the person's digital data cost for the financial year is worked out using that method;
(c) if:
(i) the person is a digital data service provider in relation to that financial year; and
(ii) the person is not a digital data service provider in relation to that financial year because of the operation of a selection system determined under section 26C or 26D; and
(iii) a determination is in force under subsection (4) in relation to that financial year;
the person's digital data cost for the financial year is worked out in accordance with the determination;
(d) if:
(i) the person is a digital data service provider in relation to that financial year; and
(ii) the person is not a digital data service provider in relation to that financial year because of the operation of a selection system determined under section 26C or 26D; and
(iii) no determination is in force under subsection (4) in relation to that financial year;
then:
(iv) if the amount worked out using the formula in subsection (3) is greater than zero dollars—the person's digital data cost for the financial year is equal to that amount; or
(v) if the amount worked out using the formula in subsection (3) is not greater than zero dollars—the person's digital data cost for the financial year is zero dollars.

(2) For the purposes of this section, if a person is a digital data service provider for an area in relation to a financial year, the person's customer equipment costs for the financial year is an amount equal to the sum of:
(a) the total costs incurred by the person in acquiring customer equipment that:

(i) is covered by a declaration that was in force under section 46B during the financial year in relation to charges imposed, or proposed to be imposed, by the person for the supply of customer equipment of a kind specified in regulations made for the purposes of paragraph 14A(1)(a) or (5)(a); and
(ii) was supplied by the person during the financial year to persons in the area; and

(b) the total rebates that became payable during the financial year by the person, in accordance with regulations made for the purposes of subsection 19A(8), in respect of customer equipment acquired or hired by persons in the area.
(3) The formula referred to in paragraph (1)(d) is as follows:
Customer equipment costs—Customer charges + Supplementary amount
where:

customer charges means the total amount payable by persons in the area referred to in subsection (2) by way of charges for the supply by the person during the financial year of customer equipment covered by paragraph (2)(a).
customer equipment costs means the person's customer equipment costs for the financial year.

The following is a simplified outline of this Part.
• This Part prohibits unacceptable conduct by telephone sex service providers, and carriage service providers, in relation to telephone sex services.
• Conduct is unacceptable if the customer:
(a) has not agreed in writing to the supply of telephone sex services; and
(b) has not been issued with a Personal Identification Number or some other means of limiting access by other persons to the telephone sex service.

• If a carriage service provider engages in unacceptable conduct in relation to a telephone sex service, charges for the service must not be included in a bill sent by or on behalf of the carriage service provider to the customer concerned.
• The supply of other goods and services must not be tied to the supply of a telephone sex service.
• The regulations may prohibit or regulate the supply, advertising or promotion of a specified telephone sex service.

para.inline: 158B Unacceptable conduct in relation to a telephone sex service

subdebate.1.para: (1) A telephone sex service provider or a carriage service provider must not engage in unacceptable conduct in relation to a telephone sex service (within the meaning of subsection (2)).
Note: Telephone sex service provider is defined by section 158K.
(2) For the purposes of this Part, if:
(a) a telephone sex service provider uses a standard telephone service to supply a telephone sex service to an end-user in Australia; and
(b) the supply is by way of a voice call; and
(c) a person (the relevant customer ) is a customer of a carriage service provider in relation to the voice call; and
(d) a charge for the supply of the telephone sex service is expected to be included in a bill sent by or on behalf of the carriage service provider to the relevant customer;
the telephone sex service provider and the carriage service provider are taken to have engaged in unacceptable conduct in relation to the telephone sex service unless:
(e) the relevant customer has agreed in writing to the use of the standard telephone service to supply telephone sex services in general; and
(f) the telephone sex service provider has reason to believe that:

(i) the relevant customer has been issued with a Personal Identification Number that provides a means of limiting access by other persons to telephone sex services supplied using the standard telephone service; or
(ii) the relevant customer has been provided with some other means of limiting access by other persons to telephone sex services supplied using the standard telephone service; and
(g) the telephone sex service provider has reason to believe that:
(i) if subparagraph (f)(i) applies—the end-user of the telephone sex service has used the Personal Identification Number referred to in that subparagraph to access the telephone sex service; or
(ii) if subparagraph (f)(ii) applies—the end-user of the telephone sex service has used the other means referred to in that subparagraph to access the telephone sex service; and
(h) the voice call is made to a number with an approved prefix.
Note 1: Telephone sex service is defined by section 158J.
Note 2: Approved prefix is defined by section 158H.
(3) Subsection (1) is a civil penalty provision .
Note: Part 31 of the Telecommunications Act 1997 provides for pecuniary penalties for breaches of civil penalty provisions. Subsection (1) is a civil penalty provision for the purposes of that Act.

para.inline: 158C Supply of goods or services not to be tied to the supply of telephone sex services

para.inline: 158D Regulations may prohibit or regulate certain telephone sex services

subdebate.1.para: (1) The regulations may prohibit or regulate any or all of the following:

talker.name: McGauran, Peter, MP
Mr McGAURAN
talker.role: Arts and the Centenary of Federation

talk.start.para: —I move:

speech.para: That all the amendments be agreed to.

I turn first to the amendments to the Telstra (Transition to Full Private Ownership) Bill 1998 . Amendment (5) omits schedule 3 of the bill to remove the provisions providing for the sale of more than 49.9 per cent of Telstra. The government recognises that a majority in the other place does not at this stage support legislation which permits a sale beyond 49.9 per cent. Amendment (1) changes the short title of the bill to Telstra (Further Dilution of Public Ownership) Bill 1999 as a consequence of the omission of schedule 3. Amendments (2), (3) and (4) make minor changes to the commencement and enacting clauses consequential on the omission of schedule 3.

I turn now to the amendments to the Telecommunications (Consumer Protection and Service Standards) Bill 1998 . In order to provide greater visibility and clarity, the Telecommunications (Consumer Protection and Service Standards) Bill 1998 brings together the consumer protection measures that were contained in the Telecommunications Act 1997.

In regard to digital data service obligation, the amendments to the bill implement the government's election commitment to include in the universal service obligation certain digital data requirements—namely, access to ISDN on demand for 96 per cent of the population; and, for the four per cent not able to access ISDN on demand, the provision of an on-demand Internet based satellite service that delivers a satellite downlink comparable to a 64 kilobits per second service as well as reimbursement of 50 per cent of the price of purchasing the necessary satellite receiving equipment. Amendments (1) to (4) and (6) to (38) insert new provisions into the universal service regime contained in the bill to include a `digital data service obligation'. These amendments will ensure equitable access to advanced communications services for regional Australia.

Turning to the customer service guarantee, part 5 of the Telecommunications (Consumer Protection and Service Standards) Bill 1998 continues the operation of the customer service guarantee arrangements contained in part 9 of the Telecommunications Act. The customer service guarantee is referred to as the CSG. Amendment (39) will enhance the operation of the CSG by providing for the automatic payment of damages to customers in relation to a contravention of the CSG without the customer having to make a specific claim for payment. Amendment (40) will give a carriage service provider a right to obtain a contribution to the damages where a contravention of the CSG is wholly or partly attributable to the acts or omissions of another carriage service provider.

In regard to telephone sex services, amendments (5) and (41) deal with the regulation of telephone sex services. Amendment (41) introduces a new part 9A into the bill containing detailed provisions for the regulation of these services. Part 9A will prohibit unacceptable conduct by telephone sex service providers and carriage service providers in relation to telephone sex services. This new part is intended to address community concerns that telephone sex lines are too easily accessed by children of standard telephone service customers.

Under the proposed amendments, before a telephone sex service which is billed on a telephone account is supplied, the phone customer must have agreed in writing to the supply of telephone sex services and been issued with a personal identification number, PIN, or some other means of limiting access by others to the telephone sex service. Such services will have to be supplied from a special number range such as 1901 numbers. If a carriage service provider engages in unacceptable conduct in relation to a telephone sex service, charges for the service will not be able to be included in a bill sent by, or on behalf of, the provider to the customer concerned.

These arrangements are not proposed for the purpose of closing down the telephone sex industry. The arrangements allow the industry to operate by providing for the services to be supplied where telephone customers have opted in or where the telephone sex service customer pays for the service otherwise than by the telephone account: for example, by using a credit card. Telephone sex service providers and carriage service providers will have a period of six months after the commencement of the bill to put arrangements in place to enable them to comply with part 9A. Regulations will be able to prohibit or regulate the supply, advertising or promotion of a specified telephone sex service.

I turn now to the amendments to the Telecommunications Legislation Amendment Bill 1998 . (Extension of time granted) I acknowledge the courtesy extended to me and the cooperation of the opposition. The amendments to the Telecommunications Legislation Amendment Bill 1998 mainly make changes to provisions dealing with the competition regulation provisions for telecommunications in the Trade Practices Act 1974. The amendments further enhance the pro-competitive framework, making changes identified through additional consultation with industry and the ACCC and the Senate legislation committee process.

In summary, the amendments enhance the ACCC's ability under part XIB of the Trade Practices Act to respond to anti-competitive conduct in the telecommunications sector, enhance the ACCC's ability under part XIC of the Trade Practices Act to arbitrate access disputes in the telecommunications sector and make a number of beneficial housekeeping amendments.

In regard to competition notice provisions, amendments (1) to (5) and (10) enhance the competition notice provisions by making it clear that the definition of anticompetitive conduct includes the taking advantage of substantial market power in a market and engaging in other conduct on one or more occasions, with the combined effect, or likely combined effect, of substantially lessening competition in the telecommunications market; by clarifying that the threshold for the issue of a competition notice is `reason to believe' rather than `being satisfied' that a contravention has occurred; by enabling the ACCC to issue simpler, and therefore more easily drafted, competition notices; by enabling the ACCC to make minor variations to a competition notice; by enabling the ACCC to continue to build its case after it has issued a part A notice by issuing part B notices which have evidentiary effect in court; by enabling the ACCC to advise a person in receipt of a notice what changes a person might make to its conduct so that it is no longer acting anticompetitively; and by substantially changing incentives to challenge notices by ensuring they remain `on foot' during the hearing of an appeal. These amendments generally represent changes that the ACCC has sought to enable it to administer the provisions more effectively.

In regard to arbitration provisions, amendments (7) to (9) enhance the access arbitration process by enabling the ACCC to make interim access determinations as well as to backdate any or all provisions of a final determination. These amendments also reduce the incentive to challenge determinations by providing that determinations will, as a default, continue to operate during such reviews—which reverses the current arrangements—and they will ensure that commissioners are not disqualified from conducting arbitrations because of past involvement in other telecommunications regulatory activities.

Amendments (6) and (7) include housekeeping amendments which will help address delays in the declaration of services where combined inquiries are undertaken and ensure that the withdrawal of an access dispute does not nullify obligations which it is appropriate should continue. Amendment (11) includes a transitional provision in the bill and amendments (12) to (16) make amendments consequential to the amendments to the Telecommunications (Consumer Protection and Service Standards) Bill to regulate telephone sex services and make digital data services part of the universal service obligation.

In conclusion, these amendments reflect changes requested by the ACCC and address the fundamental claims of industry but in a way which retains an appropriate balance of all interests. The government is confident that the amendments will enhance the effectiveness of the pro-competitive regime for telecommunications and support the further development of a competitive environment for the supply of efficient and effective telecommunications services.

Briefly, the Telecommunications (Universal Service Levy) Amendment Bill 1998 makes minor consequentials amendments to the Telecommunications (Universal Service Levy) Act 1997. A further amendment is required consequential upon the amendments to the Telecommunications (Consumer Protection and Service Standards) Bill providing for a new digital data service. Amendment (1) amends the long title of the Telecommunications (Universal Service Levy) Act of 1997 as a consequence of applying the universal service levy to the provision of digital data services. I commend the amendments to the House.

talk.start.para: —To suit the convenience of the House and the minister I will indicate how the opposition proposes to approach the debate, given we have this slightly unusual procedure as a consequence of the suspension of standing orders and the motion moved by the minister. We are dealing with four out of the five bills in the original Telstra package, the fifth bill not being amended in the Senate. So far as the Telstra (Transition to Full Private Ownership) Bill 1998 is concerned, the opposition opposes that bill in its entirety and as a consequence opposes the amendments from the Senate. We are opposed to the sale of a further 16 per cent of Telstra, just as we were opposed to the government's original legislation when it passed through this House—legislation which was to effectively authorise, by a sham inquiry, the full sale of Telstra.

speech.para: As to the second bill, the Telecommunications (Consumer Protection and Service Standards) Bill 1998 , we in general terms support that legislation. We support the amendments that have been made in respect of digital data. But we pursued amendments in respect of the telephone sex services in the Senate and we will re-run those amendments here because we believe the regime which the government has imposed on this industry is not as flexible as it could have been.

As to the third bill, in general terms we support the Telecommunications Legislation Amendment Bill 1998 and we support the amendments. There are a couple of amendments which we had on the Notice Paper in the Senate which in the course of the guillotine were lost, and I will ask the minister some questions about those. I also give the minister notice that on 16 June his colleague the Minister for Communications, Information Technology and the Arts received a formal letter from industry commenting on the amendments as adopted but also raising further questions in respect of the competitive regime. I will inquire of the minister whether the government is in a position to make a formal response to the issues raised by that letter. There is no difficulty in respect of the fourth bill in the package, the Telecommunications (Universal Service Levy) Amendment Bill 1998 or those amendments.

In terms of the procedure, if these bills were treated separately, which was the way in which they were first introduced into this House, we would have opposed on division the amendments to the Telstra privatisation bill and opposed that message. So far as the Telecommunications (Consumer Protection and Service Standards) Bill 1998 is concerned, we would have opposed the government's telephone sex regime and moved amendments in respect of that and divided on them. On defeat, I expect, of those amendments, we would have opposed that portion of the amendments. If the telecommunications legislation bill and the Telecommunications (Universal Service Levy) Amendment Bill 1998 were treated separately, we would have supported those after modest inquiries of the minister.

The procedure which the minister has adopted for today's debate, as the Manager of Opposition Business indicated, is not the most ideal way of doing it. It restricts our flexibility in some respects but it does enable us to place on the record the points that we wish to make. The minister has formally moved that all the amendments of the Senate be agreed to, but I now move:
That the following words be added to the motion:
"except that
(1) the House opposes the Senate amendments to the Telstra (Transition to Full Private Ownership) Bill and opposes the Bill itself; and
(2) Senate Amendment 41 to the Telecommunications (Consumer Protection and Service Standards) Bill 1998 be amended as follows:
(A) Proposed section 158B (pages 21 and 22) omit paragraphs 158B (2)(e), (f), (g) and (h), substitute:
(e) the voice call is made to a number with an approved prefix;
and one of the following paragraphs applies:
(f) the relevant customer has agreed:
(i) in writing; or
(ii) by telephone or other electronic means;
to the use of a carriage service to supply telephone sex services in general and the carriage service provider is satisfied as to the identity of the relevant customer;
(g) the telephone sex service provider has reason to believe that:

(i) the relevant customer has been issued with a Personal Identification Number under an access arrangement with a telephone sex service provider that is determined by the ACA to be an appropriate access arrangement; and
(ii) the end user of the telephone sex service has used the Personal Identification Number referred to in subparagraph (i) to access the telephone sex service;
(h) the telephone sex service provider has reason to believe that:

(i) the relevant customer has been issued with some other means, approved by the ACA, of limiting access to other persons to telephone sex services supplied using a carriage service (an approved access limitation means ); and
(ii) the end-user of the telephone sex service has used the approved access limitation means referred to in subparagraph (i) to access the telephone sex service.
(B) After proposed section 158G (page 24), insert:

(1) For the purposes of this Part, an access arrangement between a relevant customer and a telephone sex service provider for the provision of access to telephone sex services supplied using a voice call to a carriage service is an appropriate access arrangement if the arrangement is an arrangement of a kind specified in a written determination made by the ACA for the purposes of this subsection.
(2) The minimum requirements for an appropriate access arrangement are as follows:
(a) a customer must make an application to a service provider for a Personal Identification Number;

(b) the telephone sex service provider must not issue a Personal Identification Number to a customer without first receiving an application from the customer and unless the telephone sex service provider also provides the customer with an identity authentication card;
(c) before issuing an identity authentication card, the telephone sex service provider must verify the customer's identity in a manner determined by the ACA;

(d) the identity authentication card must be linked to an automated verification system to which the customer may gain access using a telephone service with a 1800 prefix or other prefix as determined from time to time by the ACA;

(e) the customer may use any suitable telephone to gain access to telephone sex services following customer verification through the automated verification system using the identity authentication card and Personal Identification Number;

(f) the ACA must consult with carriage service providers, telephone sex service providers and bodies that, in the opinion of the ACA, represent carriage service providers or telephone sex service providers before determining that an access arrangement is an appropriate access arrangement.
(3) A determination under subsection (1) is a disallowable instrument for the purposes of section 46A of the Acts Interpretation Act 1901 .
(C) After proposed section 158G (page 24) insert:

(1) For the purposes of this Part, a means of limiting access to telephone sex services supplied using a voice call to a carriage service is an approved access limitation means if the means is of a kind specified in a written determination made by the ACA for the purposes of this subsection.

(2) The ACA must not make a determination under subsection (1) without first consulting carriage service providers, telephone sex service providers and bodies that, in the opinion of the ACA, represent carriage service providers or telephone sex service providers .
(3) A determination under subsection (1) is a disallowable instrument for the purposes of section 46A of the Acts Interpretation Act 1901 .
(D) Proposed section 158N (page 25), omit "6 months", substitute "12 months".
I will speak to this amendment later. I now appropriately yield the floor to the senior member from Western Australia, the Leader of the Opposition.

talk.start.para: —These bills represent, apart from a number of other things, the fact that the government have failed in a deceitful effort to privatise 100 per cent of Telstra. They went into the election campaign implying that they had effectively abandoned that objective, that they would put up a sale of 16 per cent and that then there would be a genuine inquiry. While there was a disposition to proceed from that point on to 100 per cent, that disposition was not shared by the collective National members, all of whom said, `We'll stop at 16 per cent. We'll get a few gains from the bush and it will be maintained in majority ownership.' They allowed the National Party to campaign on that point and, when this parliament reconvened, they put in place a bill for the 100 per cent sale of Telstra.

speech.para: Every single National Party member went to this last election campaign on a deceit. At least one small mercy, I suppose, from this outcome is that the deceit on their part to some extent has been made good. But, of course, it still leaves us on a course which is completely unnecessary, a course which is not supported by anything like a majority of the Australian people and a course which is to the long-term disbenefit of the budget and the long-term disbenefit of those who rely—and we all will—on affordable access to each new stage of technological development in the communications industry.

The Australian people do not trust this government in the handling of this issue and in the handling of this legislation. The Australian people do not believe that Telstra should be privatised. It is their company. It is a reasonable thing for the Australian people to expect their views to be reflected in the actions of government. One of the reasons why they do not trust it is the way in which the resources are used. Some will accept the notion of privatisation in order to retire debt, but nobody accepts the notion of privatisation in order to pork-barrel.

If you actually sit down and contemplate the enormity of this, we have here an asset which every Australian needs. We have here an asset which stands at the heart of technological development in our society and on which we will always rely, not just for the next 10 years, five years or three years—forever. It stands at the heart of this. It is making good money. It requires no taxpayer subventions. It is there as an aid to the budget; it is not a detractor from the budget. It helps the Commonwealth's fiscal performance; it does not detract from the Commonwealth's fiscal performance.

These attributes are all dismissed and laid on the altar of Liberal Party and National Party pork-barrelling. You cannot escape that. That is exactly what happens with this. We found that more than 90 per cent of the first environmental fund went to seats held by the National Party and the Liberal Party. They had a smart alec response that the terms had been encapsulated in a way that permitted that to be done legitimately. You can always put in a set of terms of reference that, when implemented by the bureaucracy, does not necessarily worry the Auditor-General, although there are features of this which did. But the outcome is not simply about those elements of the proper process if what it is devoted towards is nevertheless a political end. The political end here was selling Telstra to maintain a political hold of the National Party and the Liberal Party seats, particularly in the bush.

Then we have the example of what has happened to the Federation Fund. Quite extraordinary things have been revealed about that in the Senate estimates committee hearings in recent times. At least a dozen Public Service determinate outcomes were overridden by ministers, all of which coincided with problems being experienced in particular seats by our political opponents.

Now we come to this little exercise. One of the elements of the so-called social bonus is going to be devoted to rural transaction centres. Whom do we find heading up the list of the folk who are going to determine how those rural transaction centres are selected and where they will ultimately be located? It is none other than Mr Russell Broadbent and Mr Noel Hicks—in one case a retired member and in the other case a defeated member. (Extension of time granted) They are going to be responsible for the disbursement of this. These are extraordinary things. Here we have a massive asset that everybody in this country understands is critical to their future simply being frittered away for a temporary gain for our political opponents in the bush. This is not acceptable to the average Australian.

We alone in this parliament have a view about privatisation which is non-ideological. We accept that from time to time there will be public assets that ought to be privatised. That was the position we adopted when we were in government. We do not think nothing should remain in public hands; we think that, where a particular company held in government hands is going to be requiring substantial budgets and subventions in order for it to be able to survive and prosper or where it does not stand in a monopoly situation and the private sector can adequately provide, those are circumstances among others in which privatisation might be legitimate. But where something is returning a substantial profit to the budget, where it is near monopoly in many of its most important attributes or where it is performing services which are going to be more and more important as time goes by, then there is a substantial case for public ownership.

We have no ideological objection to privatising and we have no ideological objection to something in those circumstances remaining in public hands, and that is precisely what applies in the case of Telstra and what did not apply in the case of Qantas and the Commonwealth Bank. That is why we adopted one view on them and another view on this. We actually have a bit of integrity when it comes to policy in this area and we do not drive it with Labor ideology; we drive it with a commonsense approach to what is a proper issue of public management.

The argument is raised by our opponents, `You've got to sell it to retire debt,'—belied of course by the extent to which it is used for the purposes of a pork barrel. When this government came into office, whatever the blah and persiflage that has surrounded their argument, they inherited this situation: they inherited the third best position on public debt in the Western world. They talk about this huge debt that they inherited. That debt was approximately half the public debt to GDP ratio of Maggie Thatcher's Britain, approximately half the public debt to GDP ratio of Ronald Reagan's United States, less than half the public debt to GDP ratio of Helmut Kohl's Germany and—this may not necessarily be a terribly good comparison, and I will sit with those three—approximately one-fifth of the public debt to GDP ratio of Italy. So it could not be said that they faced an overwhelming budgetary requirement.

What they actually confronted was Liberal Party ideology, that is all. It was not a public debt position which drove the determination they had, but Liberal Party ideology that there should be nothing in the public sector. Even if it has a monopoly characteristic, even if it has a technology utterly essential to regional Australia—actually utterly essential to all Australians—this was irrelevant.

Then we come to the other element of public debt that is worth commenting on. Depending on which of the brokers you wish to believe and the earnings that can be expected by the sale from these shares, some time in the next five years there will be a crossover between what would be the value of this in terms of a dividend return to the budget and what will be retired and hence relief given to the public debt interest obligation upon the government. At some point there will be a crossover.

From that point on, the sale of Telstra becomes an economically disastrous decision as far as proper management of our budget is concerned. From that point on, that occurs, and it will occur within the next decade. So we will no longer have the capacity to direct Telstra to provide affordable new technologies and new services in the bush, or anywhere else for that matter. We will no longer have that, and our budget within the next five to 10 years will be for the bad: it will deal with a debt problem that does not exist in terms of any reasonable international comparison and will pork-barrel Liberal and National Party electorates. This is exceptionally bad public policy and, instinctively, the Australian people reject it. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: —Mr Deputy Speaker, thank you for the opportunity to talk in detail on the further sale of Telstra. I for one do not accept the mantle of deceit. I have never deceived the people of my electorate on where I stand on the 49 per cent issue and, indeed, nor have my colleagues. If we are in the business of deceit and we are in the business of the sale of public assets, I would like to know why the Labor Party told the Australian public that you were not going to sell the Commonwealth Bank, and then you did; that you would never sell the second half, and you did; and that you would never sell Qantas, and you did. The Leader of the Opposition argues the case that this is a commonsense policy that you have adopted. Suddenly, you have changed from being the great privateers to becoming people defending public ownership.

speech.para: I suppose there would be a lot of people in regional and rural Australia who thought there was some merit in retaining the Commonwealth Serum Laboratories. The Commonwealth Serum Laboratories had a very proud record of providing pharmaceuticals to the bush. We might have thought that was sensible.

I take some pride in this because the sale of this 16 per cent of Telstra will deliver something that I was personally involved in. I was one of the two authors of the Bundaberg resolution, which is often quoted in the media. It was a package of those things that had been neglected by the Labor Party for half a generation when they were in office. In this Bundaberg resolution, we benchmarked, if you like, seven things that the bush wanted, including reliable mobile telephony and the removal of black spots in terrestrial television reception—things that in 13 years the Labor Party had done nothing about.

The Labor Party saddled us with a digital system that was arguably going to miss 40 per cent of regional and rural Australia. Talking television, in my own electorate of Hinkler, between Bundaberg and Gladstone—two quite large provincial cities quite close to the coast—there are 3,000 to 5,000 people without adequate television. For 13 years, the current opposition did nothing about it. Now under the $120 million program that the government has undertaken to provide, not only will some of those black spots be filled but SBS will be extended to those areas. In Labor's day, SBS had to be delivered to the capital cities—it was absolutely essential; but when it came to giving it to regional and rural Australia, we confronted a torturous position that was dragged out over months and months, and many of those communities have been without SBS for many years. That is also part of that $120 million package.

I take offence to the provision of $1 billion for regional and rural Australia to give them the same entitlement to telecommunications, broadcast communications and mobile telephony that the rest of Australia takes for granted. How dare the Leader of the Opposition come into this House and say that the provision of these basic links of the community to people are pork-barrelling. It is evidence of 13 years of virulent neglect. To my way of thinking, for the government to provide $1 billion of the likely $16 billion to $18 billion of this 16.6 per cent sale of Telstra is commendable justice. The Leader of the Opposition should hang his head in shame. He has no answer. He himself had no policy initiatives. When someone sets out to fix it, all he can call it is pork-barrelling. It is pathetic.

talk.start.para: —I have listened with interest to this debate and have decided to inject myself in it to put a few thoughts on the record, particularly about regional services, which the previous speaker alluded to. These could have been achieved without the sale of Australia's icon asset, delivering as it does $3 billion at the moment and perhaps $4 billion or $5 billion down the track. As was pointed out earlier, Telstra has been at the forefront of the world's telecommunications industry. It is a world leader. It has skills that could be utilised world wide in a globalised market. We saw figures a couple of years ago that there was something like a trillion dollars worth of communications infrastructure going into South-East Asia. That was before their economic difficulties, but with that area now recovering that work will again be on the agenda. Telstra is very well positioned to take advantage of that.

speech.para: That is realised by the million or so shareholders who have taken up the shareholding. They realise the potential of this company. To hand what is now owned by Australians across to a minimal number of shareholders is an absolute disgrace. We are not talking about our future generations; we are talking about short-term, political, hard-nosed privatisation policy that is already on the nose, judging by voter response to the New South Wales coalition's power industry privatisation plans. People are finally realising that privatisation does not necessarily lead to improved services. The government can cite its transaction centres. It can do what it likes in terms of the sorts of services that should be provided anyway to the bush, but not by privatising our telecommunications entity.

Telstra was sold off in its initial phase at $3.30 a share. As we all know, they closed at $8.10 last Friday and are still on the way up. While that share price has continued to rise, the same cannot be said about services. In Orange, for example, you are lucky to get a public telephone that works. Telstra is very reluctant to keep or maintain them because of the cost of doing so. The bottom line is that the more it costs Telstra to provide services in regional areas the less profit there will be for shareholders.

Let us look at who benefits from selling Telstra. The government would have us believe that one of the greatest benefits of selling Telstra was and remains letting ordi nary mums and dads reap the rewards of share ownership. We have seen the share ownership shrink since that original float. I would suggest that many of the mums and dads have taken the profits, and good luck to them. But, undoubtedly, many such people have benefited from Telstra's spectacular performance on the stock market. Information across my desk suggests that many have benefited beyond others.

In the 1996-97 financial year, 23,500 taxpayers in Bradfield, the most affluent federal electorate, held shares for which tax rebates were available while only 6,600 people from Calare declared such shares. During the same period the average taxable income in Bradfield was $51,000, or thereabouts, while in Calare it was $30,000. While the figures do not include Telstra shareholdings, what they do show is how share ownership in Australia is concentrated among the most wealthy. It follows that those who stand to benefit most from the sale of a public asset like Telstra are people with higher incomes, a large proportion of whom live in coalition seats. But all Australians have a vested interest in Telstra. That is why if the sale of the next sixth of Telstra goes through, as it surely will, the government must stand condemned if it does not get top dollar for it. Otherwise, it will again be ripping off the millions of Australians with stakes in Telstra but no capacity to buy them back.

The $100 million that Senator Harradine has wangled out of the government is an absolute pittance when you look at the benefits that Telstra in public ownership could continue to deliver down the track, particularly so in our critical environmental area. Here we have the government sitting on a report on the salination problems that are out there, particularly in the Murray-Darling basin, and what do we have? We have procrastination, we have delay, we have no real way of handling that crisis. I believe that, by quarantining part of that $3 billion, $4 billion or $5 billion forever, we could have handled the environment problem for which we have no answer. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: —The opposition opposes the Telstra (Transition to Full Private Ownership) Bill 1998 and the amendments from the Senate. We oppose the whole bill itself, and that is reflected by the amendment that has been circulated in my name. Why do we oppose the further privatisation of Telstra? We oppose the further privatisation of Telstra because we are fearful that services to rural and regional Australia will continue to decline and decline further.

speech.para: We opposed the initial privatisation of Telstra, and one reason was that we feared that service levels to rural and regional and remote Australia would decline. Commonsense tells you that they will decline if you give Telstra a commercial orientation because they are not the great profit earners for Telstra. The last time the ACA put out a performance bulletin we saw a six per cent national decline in fault repairs to regional centres which followed on a nine per cent national decline in fault repairs for regional centres on the previous year. So, if you further privatise Telstra, you give it a further commercial orientation and service levels to rural and regional Australia will continue to decline further.

The second reason we oppose the privatisation of Telstra is that Telstra is an important part of our national infrastructure. It has been built up effectively over a century. The third reason we say that we oppose the privatisation of Telstra is that the government says, `We will flog it off and fund regional telecommunications infrastructure.' You can fund telecommunications infrastructure in one of two ways. You can do it in the short term and fund it out of privatisation, but once you flog a bit off it is gone forever—you can do it only once—or you can fund telecommunications infrastructure and other merit worthy public policy initiatives by relying on Telstra's dividend and its long-term return.

Let's put the so-called social bonus, the bribe to the bush, in perspective. It is now, after a press release on Sunday, $1 billion. That is $1 billion out of a 16 per cent privatisation, a privatisation which the market says we will get anywhere between $15 billion and $20 billion. So, if it is between $15 billion and $20 billion and the social bonus, the bribe to the bush, is $1 billion, that is about a five per cent return on a capital investment that has been built up over a century. If you put that in context, the last time Telstra reported a six-monthly profit, a half-yearly profit, it was $1.8 billion. So Telstra's last six-monthly profit was $1.8 billion, nearly twice the bribe for a 16 per cent privatisation, which will give you between $15 billion and $20 billion on current market expectation.

Even if you do not accept the fact that you are better off funding in the long term by way of its dividend, what the National Party and the coalition have gone for is a paltry bribe, a paltry bribe. Members of the National Party should be ashamed of themselves. For the Minister for the Arts and the Centenary of Federation, who is a National Party member from Victoria, to come into this House to support these amendments and support the privatisation with the Prime Minister out there saying that they are still committed slavishly to the 100 per cent privatisation of Telstra, National Party members in this House should be ashamed of themselves. No wonder the member for Dawson and the member for Kennedy are not in here at the moment.

When you look at the bribe to the bush, the original bribe was $671 million, of which $350 million would go to regional telecommunications infrastructure. The bribe we saw on the weekend was $314 million. That was done by press release, not even legislated by the government in the Senate when it guillotined this measure through. When you look at some aspects of the pork barrel there, the trap that Senator Harradine has fallen into is to accept a short-term local benefit for a long-term national loss. That is what he and Senator Colston have done by supporting this measure.

If you come from Queensland, don't bother trying to look in the press release on the weekend for a benefit for Queensland because there is no special benefit for Queensland. Whatever special benefit has occurred, it has occurred to Senator Colston, not to Queensland. And that point has been made in spades by the Deputy Premier of Western Australia, National Party leader, Hendy Cowan, who described the Regional Telecommunications Infrastructure Fund, which was funded out of the first 30 per cent privatisation, as a `disgrace', weighted as it was to Tasmania as against Western Australia, and Premier Court has described this process as a `corruption' of the process. So what Senators Harradine and Colston have effected is a short-term local gain for Tasmania but a long-term national loss for the nation. You can fund regional telecommunications infrastructure better in the long term from Telstra's dividend than you can by flogging off bits and pieces of Telstra. (Extension of time granted)

The other context in which the so-called social bonus needs to be put is the fees that have gone to the bankers and brokers from Melbourne and Sydney and offshore. With the first privatisation, the fees to the bankers and brokers was $260 million, more than the government allocated to the Regional Telecommunications Infrastructure Fund. So National Party members should be really proud of themselves on the first privatisation. You gave more to the bankers and brokers in Sydney and Melbourne than you gave to rural and regional Australia for the Telecommunications Infrastructure Fund.

When you look at the original bill that came through this House, on the government's own admission you can see that the bankers and brokers would have received $800 million to $1.1 billion in fees and commission payments on a full privatisation—an absolute disgrace and a scandal. We know from the first privatisation that the Auditor-General effectively said, `You sold it too low. The fees were too high. It was a botched job.' So do not think the Labor Party and the community will not be watching with assiduous scrutiny this next privatisation process in terms of the fees for bankers and brokers and preferment that goes to institutional shareholders or others.

We are strongly opposed to the further privatisation of Telstra. We fear that services to rural and regional Australia will continue to decline. We believe Telstra is an important part of our national infrastructure built up over 100 years, and it ought to remain in public hands. The more you privatise it the more you will ensure the commercial orientation will see a denuding of services to the bush. We believe that you are best ensuring that the provision of infrastructure is done in the long term out of Telstra's dividend.

People in the press have made the commentary that you now have a dichotomy—private ownership versus public ownership. The real dichotomy here, and the real crime of public policy other than privatisation, is that the government has now given the community a dominant market player or a monopolist, which you might have described previously as a slothful public monopoly but which now you have sought to turn into a voracious private monopoly. You have done that before you have sorted out the competitive arrangements. So the real crime here is turning and unleashing Telstra into a private oriented monopolist or dominant market player without having previously established in proper terms the access arrangements or a properly competitive marketplace.

When you look at the changes that the government has made to the telecommunications legislation which establishes the regulatory regime, whilst the amendments that the government has pursued—dragged there kicking and screaming by the industry—are in themselves okay, what real mistake has the government made here? On 1 July 1997 when the government established a competitive regime, it should have firstly made sure that the ACCC was properly resourced both in its nature and the extent of its resources. The penny did not drop for the government in that respect until recently.

Secondly, the government should have immediately identified—as every other comparable jurisdiction has—that two of the crunch issues for the competitive regime would be access to the local loop and the interconnect fee. We are still waiting to see those issues resolved in favour of a competitive marketplace. While those issues drag along, in its obsession for privatisation the government foists a voracious private monopolist or dominant market player into the marketplace without those issues having been resolved.

The great crime of public policy here is unleashing a private monopolist, turning a blind eye and dragging their feet to the competitive regime. We have been saying to the government for some time that they should bring forward the comprehensive review of the competitive arrangements, not wait for the standard departmental review in 2001 and do it properly.

The great dichotomy now is not a dichotomy between public and private. My message to Telstra management and Dr Switkowski is: `just get on with it. Telstra is not the only company in the world that has majority-minority shareholders. It is not the only telco in the world that has part-government/part-private ownership. It should just get on with it: improve your service levels and improve your competitive attitude; solve the access regime and interconnect fee issues with the ACCC, and do it quickly; and show Australia that you can do it. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: —I rise to speak very much in favour of the passage of this legislation and the sale of Telstra. I represent the largest electorate in the world. My constituents are very conscious of the shortcomings of telecommunications at present, and this sale will enable the funding of new initiatives in telecommunications which will overcome the antiquated technologies of the past and allow us to move into the new millennium with a technology that suits.
—What did you do at Kalgoorlie? Nothing!

—The interjector suggests that we are not winning in the electorate of Kalgoorlie. What the interjector does not understand is that there is far more to the electorate of Kalgoorlie than the city of Kalgoorlie-Boulder.
—She probably does not understand where it is.

—I would suggest that perhaps a lot of personal visitation has not been carried out. However, my constituents, especially those in the pastoral areas, are sick and tired of relying on antiquated radio repeater stations to communicate with the rest of the world. I will give a classic example from the Gascoigne area of my electorate of one neighbour wanting to speak to their nearest neighbour. The conversation has to go through 12 radio repeater stations, then 400 kilometres of copper line and then all the way back again. This is in order to talk to a neighbour who lives about 70 kilometres away. At almost all times of the year those facilities are affected by something or another that creates problems with that system of communications.

speech.para: This sale of Telstra will allow an injection of funds to provide state-of-the-art technology and perhaps provide for satellite communications which will not be limited by local weather conditions and will not be limited by the availability of staff, who at the moment are perhaps prevented from attending to repairs because the road infrastructure is such that they cannot get out to repeater stations to repair them.

This is a breakthrough in the availability of funds, not only to provide better facilities on the ground but also to pay off Labor's obscene debt. When we came into office there was a debt of $96 billion. It is only by the sale of such assets that we can afford to effect change to reduce the huge annual debt of paying interest on that capital borrowed and get back to an equitable situation where we can enjoy reasonably low interest rates, the benefits of which are passed onto every home buying family in Australia.

There is so much to benefit from this particular sale that it cannot be ignored. I, for one, am absolutely thrilled that the Senate has finally seen sense and will allow this sale to take place. Without this sale, we do not have the funds to provide the brand new, cutting edge technology that is so necessary in the remote areas of my electorate. This particular win for the government is quite clearly an absolute win for the bush, and my electorate of Kalgoorlie is the major part of that bush in Australia. I commend the amendments to the House.

talk.start.para: —I rise in support of the opposition's position on this telecommunica tions legislation. I am, frankly, astounded by the comments from the member for Kalgoorlie about the so-called benefits to his constituents as a result of this legislation. I have lived in very remote areas of northern Australia, and I can say without fear of contradiction that, if it were not for the fact that Telstra was able through its CSO obligations to provide telecommunication services to remote communities, there would be no communications to these remote communities; we would still be on the flying doctor radio scheds.

speech.para: The fact of the matter—and the shadow minister has, I think, made the point very succinctly—is that we are about to see the diminution of telecommunications service throughout remote Australia as a result of this sell-off. There is absolutely no doubt in my mind that the commercial imperatives that will drive an operation, 49 per cent of which is owned privately, will far outweigh the social obligations which I think a publicly owned company should have in providing for all of its citizens.

I do not want to repeat the words of the Leader of the Opposition because I think his arguments speak for themselves, and I strongly support them. For a start, I want to go to two of the proposals in this social bonus package which will supposedly give a great many benefits to rural and remote Australia. The first proposal is this magnificent sum of $3 million to extend mobile phone coverage in regional Western Australia, South Australia and Tasmania. What is wrong with the Northern Territory? If you are really concerned about remote Australia, about people in the bush, you would say, `Well, there's a fair chance that we should provide mobile phones to people who live at Port Keats or Yuendumu or Timber Creek.' This does not do it.

The second proposal is the $25 million to provide continuous mobile phone coverage along designated major highways. Whoopee! What does it do for the Barkly Highway? What does it do for the Victoria River Highway? What does it do for the Stuart Highway? What does it do for the remotest of Australian communities? Absolutely zero. If you had done some sort of sensible, needs based analysis of how you might distribute funds which you have made available through this source, a source with which I disagree because of the benefit we would otherwise accrue over time, as the Leader of the Opposition said, and if you accept, as members of the government do—I do not—the legitimacy of this approach, you would have applied some reasonable, rational criteria to need. But no criteria have been applied in this approach.

Then we have the approach of providing SBS services to communities of over 10,000 people. Why 10,000 people? I note that the Prime Minister had a go at me the other day about Alice Springs. For the information of the government, and in particular the Prime Minister, there has been a self-help scheme in Alice Springs since 1995. We have had SBS since 1995. Does that register? I wonder how much this government really understand about remote Australia. If they want to extend SBS, they should be saying, `Let's do it equitably.' There is no equity in this package. There is the bribe to Tasmania. Why should the children of Tasmania achieve a $15 million benefit that does not go to other Australian students?

talk.start.para: —They have got the greatest need.

interjection.para: Mr Haase interjecting—

talk.start.para: —Well, mate, I suggest you go for a swim, cool down, because you have got absolutely no idea about need. You have got no idea about the educational needs of people who live in remote Australia. And the person sitting behind you, the member for Kalgoorlie, should understand, if he does not already, that the most disadvantaged people educationally in Australia are those people in his electorate and my electorate—not the people in Moreton and not the people in Tasmania. Just look at the educational outcomes of Aboriginal communities in your electorate. Look at the educational outcomes of Aboriginal communities in my electorate. They are not going to benefit by this $15 million. There is no equity in this package. It should be opposed not only because of its lack of equity but also because it is an outright bribe. There is, in my view, nothing in this package to satisfy the demand. (Time expired)

—I am fascinated by the opposition's position on this. In fact, they are all over the place. One minute they are calling Telstra a national icon, something to be preserved, put in a glass case; the next minute the shadow minister at the table suggests to us it might have been better to leave it as a slothful public monopoly. I think that is extraordinary. I pose the question: if it was a slothful public monopoly over the 13 years Labor were in power, are the service and installation difficulties we are experiencing today necessarily a dimension of lack of focus at present by Telstra or are they a result of the accumulated lack of interest over the years? Finally, having first had it as an icon and then as a slothful public monopoly, the opposition now turn round and call it a voracious commercial monopoly. You cannot have it three different ways all the time.

speech.para: Mr Hardgrave interjecting—

talk.start.para: —You could satisfy all three factions with the three titles, exactly.

speech.para: Opposition members interjecting—

talk.start.para: —I will get to the shadow minister for regional services. I say to the opposition: you had 13 years to fix this. You left Australia's mobile telephony in a shocking mess. In fact, at the end of next year—if it had not been for your appalling mishandling of cable—the people of Australia would have had much better telecommunications. The Leader of the Opposition calls this pork-barrelling. To give $1 billion back to the bush is pork-barrelling, is it? I wonder whether it is because you no longer hold any reasonable seats in the bush. It can wither on the vine like it did in the 13 years that you were in power. You let it wither on the vine.

speech.para: Honourable members interjecting—

talk.start.para: —My word, yes. I will look after Capricornia, don't worry about that. If it is not looked after, I will look after it. I would like to pose a few questions. Not only is there rampant—
—Socialists in the bush.

—Yes, that'll be the day! Not only is there rampant hypocrisy on the part of the opposition, not only did they stuff it up when they were in power, but I put it to you which of these are pork-barrelling—

speech.para: Mr O'Connor interjecting—

talk.start.para: —Order! If the member for Corio wishes to interject he should resume his seat.
—Which of these are pork-barrelling: $150 million to upgrade telecommunications infrastructure in extended zones, to give people the—

speech.para: Opposition members interjecting—

talk.start.para: —Order! The honourable member for Hinkler will resume his seat. I remind honourable members on my left that there is an opportunity for them to stand and participate in the debate.
—I want to know: is providing extended zones for people who were neglected over 13 years pork-barrelling? That is people right across Australia—

speech.para: Mr Snowdon interjecting—

talk.start.para: —including the Northern Territory. If $120 million for SBS that you were going to allow to go on for years in advance has been pulled back to some reasonable limit, is that unreasonable?

speech.para: Opposition members interjecting—

talk.start.para: —Is it pork-barrelling to fill the black spots that you left neglected right across electorates, including the electorate of Capricornia you mentioned earlier? Where is the pork-barrelling in the $70 million to replace the banks that have left regional Australia, the $70 million for the BARN program, the $45 million to bring local government online, the $36 million to improve Internet services and the $25 million to fix up mobile telephones? (Time expired)
—It is very appropriate that we are talking about selling here, because who has sold out the most in this debate? The Queensland Nationals, who went to the last election—

speech.para: Opposition members interjecting—

talk.start.para: —Version No. 1 was, `We won't allow one more per cent of Telstra to be sold.' Version No. 2 was, `All right, we'll let 16 per cent more go but only if there is an independent inquiry which recommends the sale of the rest.' What a sell-out. On the question of what pork-barrelling is, I say to the member for Hinkler, in the words of the editorial from the Canberra Times :

speech.para: The government which came into power pledging to govern for all Australians has elevated the art of pork-barrelling to new heights with its Telstra deal.

And we know it to be true. I want to talk about the propaganda associated with the double-speak term `social bonus'. Let us call this social bonus exactly what it is. A great, big, fat bribe. Let us note that this government has said that Australians who live in rural and regional areas can have fair access to telecommunications infrastructure only if Australia's best performing asset is sold. In other words, `You can have this bonus not as a right but only if you let us sell our best performing Australian owned asset.' By contrast, the New South Wales government has just paid for every country small business operator to be connected to the Net—not as a social bonus, not as some disgusting trade-off but because it is the right thing to do. It is a right which the government in New South Wales is prepared to fund. It is not a shonky bribe.

The Queensland Nationals at the federal level have allowed themselves to be both duped and silenced. Where is Mr Katter today? Where is Mrs Kelly today? Just the lone member for Hinkler trying to defend the indefensible. The Nationals have allowed themselves to willingly contribute to the emasculation of Telstra, because agreeing to the next 16 per cent has made it all the more inevitable that you will capitulate to this Prime Minister when he says, `Let us have the rest.' And you have fooled nobody in your actions.

The second element of this wonderful double-speak we hear in here every day in question time is, `Mums and dads can now buy shares in Telstra,' which conveniently and dishonestly overlooks the reality that every Australian owned shares in Telstra. Everybody used to own 100 per cent of Telstra. All Australians used to share in the spending of the Telstra dividend on services for all Australians. How can it be honest, how can it be fair and how can it be democratic to take away something from those who own it and then resell it to those who can afford to buy shares? Nobody begrudges anyone the right to buy shares, but this is a shonky deal because you are stealing from those who already own. You are selling it at undervalued prices and in that way you are robbing the public coffers of even what is left. That is the point.

The Herald Sun poll today says over 80 per cent of Australians say, `Do not sell the rest of Telstra.' And they also said, `Do not sell one per cent more of Telstra,' before the last election. Three thousand five hundred votes out of 12 million votes does not give you a mandate. The Nationals have betrayed country Australians. John Howard has betrayed all Australians with this dishonest bribe and this dishonest and unauthorised action in selling another 16 per cent of Telstra.

It is possible to fund the social bonus by dedicating a proportion of the Telstra dividend as of right to regional infrastructure. You have been bribed, you have sold yourselves short and you have allowed Telstra to be emasculated. Go and answer country Australians on that charge. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: —I just want to make some brief comments on the accompanying legislation. I made some comments earlier about the telecommunications legislation competitive regime, and I have previously drawn the attention of the minister at the table to the letter to the Minister for Communications, Information Technology and the Arts dated 16 June from the various carriers raising further competitive matters. I indicated that I would go through those but, if the minister is happy for me to do so, I am happy to take a response to that on notice. I see the minister nodding in agreement. I treat that as his usual undertaking.

speech.para: So far as the consumer protection legislation is concerned, there are two areas I would like to comment on. One is the digital data amendments. People should understand the history of this. In the run-up to the 1996 election, the now government made a commitment that it would extend ISDN capacity to everyone. At the time, we said from government, `You need to understand what you are committing yourselves to because you won't be able to afford that and, when you get into government, you won't do it.' That is precisely what occurred.

Minister, you and your colleagues bagged us uphill and down dale for saying what we said, and we were right. You then sent it off to Tony Shaw at the ACA who rescued you and came back to enable you to have a commitment for the 1998 election saying, `Whoops. What the Labor Party said from government responsibly in 1996 in the run-up to that election was correct.' You cannot do it and fund it properly, so you come up with a half-baked solution. The advisers are smiling in the box because they know the truth, and so do you, Minister, because you are smiling as well. The four per cent ISDN is half a service.

Minister, you should please understand that the expectations you have raised will be dashed in the rural and regional community. You have been making loud noises about connecting the bush to the electronic Internet world. You had an opportunity here to deliver something of real substance and some real advantage to those in the community isolated from the information economy. You fumbled the ball, and you are effectively providing a substandard service. The community will come to know this reasonably quickly, I am sure. Your amendment effectively locks people into a particular carrier, and the high-speed lines will be loaded down with slow up-line speeds restricted to whatever cable or copper connection they have.

The second area I want to very quickly refer to is the amendments that I have circulated in respect of the government's proposals on telephone sex. We have made the point in the Senate that we believe in an opt-in regime. In general terms, we support that view, which is also the government's view. Your opt-in regime is too restrictive and effectively too onerous a burden for the industry.

Our amendments seek to make it a sensible opt-in regime to enable it to work flexibly. We believe that opt-in is preferable in this area because it is a question of consumer protection. We have all, as members of parliament, had mums and dads come into the office saying, `Here is a telephone bill that I wasn't expecting. Someone in the family, a friend or someone has been using a 0055—in the old days—or 1900 phone sex line. I am now copping the bill.' That is why we say, `Opt-in.' Our amendments make that an effective and sensible opt-in regime.

We suspect, Minister, that your motives are coloured by other things, like encouraging Senator Harradine to vote for you. I have become increasingly concerned about the collateral industry damage to telephone service providers. Telephone service providers, in Western Australia for example, who provide the telephone service to the adult sex lines also provide telephone services for the Western Australia newspapers, radio 94.5, Stockphone Pty Ltd—which provides ASIC information—Agriculture WA farm notes, junior soccer fixtures and the like. The collateral industry damage you will cause there will be quite significant.

I note that there has been some reporting about the way in which this matter was handled in the Senate. I also note that Senator Colston is refusing to say how he voted on that matter. I was in the Senate, regrettably, on that night and I can tell you how Senator Colston voted. When the government's amendment was put, there was one voice in opposition to it—that was the Labor Party. Senator Harradine and Senator Colston were with the government on the other side, and the Democrats and the Greens were silent. We are used to Senator Colston saying one thing and doing another. We have copped that big time. People out there who thought they had an undertaking from Senator Colston should please understand on this issue that he voted with the government and Senator Harradine to knock off our amendments and to put in the government's regime. (Time expired)

talker.name: McGauran, Peter, MP
Mr McGAURAN
talker.role: Arts and the Centenary of Federation

talk.start.para: —As entertaining as the rantings and ravings of the opposition may be, it is time to move on. I move:

speech.para: That the question be now put.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Question put: That the amendment (Mr Smith's) be agreed to.
The House divided. [12.09 p.m.]
(Mr Deputy Speaker—Mr H.V. Quick)
Voting details are recorded in the Votes and Proceedings.
Question so resolved in the negative.
Original question resolved in the affirmative.

subdebate.1.para: Debate resumed from 13 May, on motion by Mr Moore:
That the bill be now read a second time.
upon which Mr McMullan moved by way of amendment:
That all words after "That" be omitted with a view to substituting the following words:

"while not declining to give the bill a second reading, the House expresses its concern about the failure of the Government to provide for a review of the future of the automotive industry before tariffs are reduced in 2005".

talk.start.para: —The ACIS Administration Bill 1999 , the ACIS (Unearned Credit Liability) Bill 1999 and the Customs Tariff Amendment (ACIS Implementation) Bill 1999 are very important pieces of legislation to the future of the car industry and component manufacturing in Australia. They are very important also to the Corio electorate, which encompasses the great city of Geelong, because we have located there a major car manufacturing plant as well as a significant car component manufacturing capacity.

speech.para: The Customs Tariff Amendment (ACIS Implementation) Bill 1999 implements the tariff pause. The ACIS Administration Bill 1999 and the ACIS (Unearned Credit Liability) Bill 1999 implement the transitional assistance arrangements for the car industry. These will be very important if the industry is to prepare itself for the program of tariff reductions that have been signalled by the government in this legislation.

The car industry is extremely important to my electorate.
