But in our tax package we are doing something which the small business sector has asked for, called for and demanded for years and years and years to reduce red tape—namely, to establish a new simplified administration for tax compliance. We are doing that in our tax policy so that in future small businesses will have to spend less time on tax compliance and more time running their businesses and creating jobs. That is an integrated approach.

We have cut government spending in key areas. Why? Because we inherited a budget deficit of $10.3 billion. By getting into a situation of a balanced budget, we have taken the pressure off interest rates and that has reduced costs for business. Why is that good? That is good because they have more money in their pockets and they can spend that money on employing people, growing their business, and that is good for their customers, too. With house mortgage rates down by $330 a month, they have more money in their pockets. That is more buying power. That is good for our businesses and that means more jobs. Wherever you look in the government's panoply of policies we are working at, driving at, creating a system that will see more jobs.

When we came into office in March 1996 we inherited a problem that was established by the previous Labor government back in 1993. That was a provision in the industrial laws of this country that would see the end of junior wage rates in 1997. If you abolished junior wage rates overnight, that would be a disaster for young people. We really need to focus on the extent of the catastrophe that that would be. There are about 400,000 young people—namely, people under 21—who are employed on junior wage rates in the system. It is a good system. Gee, it is a good system. There would be a lot of people in this chamber today listening to these proceedings who got their first job as a junior and it gave them a chance to put their foot on the first step of the ladder. Okay, they might have got only 50 per cent or 60 per cent of the adult rate, but it was a job—it was a chance to show what they could do, it was a chance to get some experience, to mature. One of my colleagues the member for Cowper has his hand up.

Junior wage rates is a system we have had for a long time. It is a good system and we would be crazy to get rid of it. About 400,000 young people are employed under that system today. The figures show that if you abolish junior wage rates then something like 160,000 or 170,000 out of 400,000 jobs—so that is nearly half of the jobs for young people—would be lost. For the economy as a whole, it would actually mean fewer jobs as well because for every two young people who lose a job then in some businesses one adult might keep a job or be employed in the future. So there would be a mass loss of jobs throughout the economy, but young people would bear the brunt of the abolition of junior wage rates.

We inherited a system from Labor that would have seen the end of those junior wage rates in June 1997. We said to the Democrats, `We ought to just legislate to keep the system.' They said, `No, no.' They were concerned about discrimination on the grounds of age and they persuaded us to hold a commission inquiry into the whole issue. We said, `Fair enough, but the report should focus on the disemploying effects of the abolition of junior wage rates.' We were prepared to go along with the report, but it was on the condition that the abolition of junior wage rates would be deferred for three years. That is how we have got to where we are today.

We established the inquiry through amendments to the Workplace Relations Act, and the Industrial Relations Commission have gone off, brought all the parties together, called publicly for submissions and sat down over a six- to nine-month period and examined every last aspect of this issue. I pay tribute to the commission for the professionalism and the comprehensive nature of their report. They have looked at absolutely everything that has been discussed on this issue for years. It is not a new issue.

The trade union movement and the Labor Party are basically opposed to junior rates. The unions' idea of a job is a full-time job basically for an adult and usually for a male. That is basically how the system has been constructed. The world has changed. There are a lot more women who want to be in the work force, so we have been making changes to make it more flexible so they can have a job that particularly allows them to balance work and family responsibilities. As time goes on, the blokes will take, and are taking, more family responsibilities. So we need a system that helps them as well—not just the mums but also the dads—in balancing work and family responsibilities. The world has changed, but the system of junior wage rates has continued to provide a very useful opportunity for young people to have a job. The commission took submissions from a wide range of parties and looked at each of the issues.

The government have been mounting the case. In fact, we took our policy position to the people in the 1998 election. Back in 1996 we did not know when the next election was. We still were of the view that we should keep age based junior rates and we said to the Democrats, `We are happy to set up this process of report. But understand that we have a policy and we are not budging from our policy because it is too important for young people.' So in the 1998 election we had an absolutely clear, unambiguous policy: if we were elected, we would keep age based junior rates.

So we introduced that legislation, and then we were attacked by the Labor Party for trying to implement a policy that we took to the last election. They attacked us on the basis that we should await the commission's report. Well, we now have the commission's report, and when you go through each and every element of the commission's report it comprehensively supports virtually every aspect of what we put to the commission and which we have argued in this place and publicly. I just want to run through the principal elements and refer you to the actual specifics in the commission report that substantiate these particular propositions. These are the conclusions of the commission. Firstly, they say:
There is an indisputable relationship between junior rates, their potential abolition and the employment prospects of young people.

I refer you to pages 157 and 165 and others if you would like the detail. That should not be an extraordinary proposition, but it is one that the Labor Party has basically been opposing—certainly the ACTU has. It is a commonsense conclusion for the commission to come to. If you get rid of junior wage rates, there will be job losses. Secondly, they say:

A discounted pay rate for entry level work continues to be necessary in the areas in which employment under junior rate classifications is most concentrated and that well-designed junior rate classifications may even create or protect employment opportunities including in the building and construction industries.

This is, again, an absolutely critical point. It is not just about protecting jobs; we are trying to create jobs. For heaven's sake, we have a high youth unemployment rate: it is 23 per cent or 24 per cent—that is a level that is far too high. Everything we can do to create jobs we ought to. And here is the commission saying in their independent report that junior rate classifications can actually help young people get a job that they cannot get today. Thirdly, they say:
The system of junior rates has been used as a wage reference for young people for decades. It is simple to understand and administer and has active employment under it.
Those two centre points are very important: `it is simple to understand and administer'.

In the labour market, if you are running a corner shop and you have to give somebody a job, you do not want to have to read a book to explain what the wage rate ought to be. It has to be a system that ordinary people can understand. The junior age base system is a system that people understand. It is pretty straightforward. It has been used, it is effective and we know it works. The commission makes that point. It is a pity the Labor Party still fails to understand that very simple point but a terribly commonsense one for anybody running a business, particularly a small business.

They go on to say that none of the proposed alternatives to junior rates are feasible because they are either more complex, overvalue the work of employees, are themselves discriminatory or have considerable adverse cost effects. This conclusion by the commission is sweet irony, because the Labor Party is going around saying, `We want to get rid of these shocking, heinous, discriminatory provisions and we will set up an alternative that is non-discriminatory.' The Leader of the Opposition has been publicly signed up to the shoppies position, but the commission looked at what the shoppies were saying and found that it is actually discriminatory. In other words, the Labor Party is saying, `Get rid of junior rates because it is discriminatory and here is our alternative,' but now we know the alternative is discriminatory.

What does that mean in practical terms? It is hard to know which is the Labor Party's policy but, taking the speech that he made not so long ago on this issue, for them to implement their policy they need our legislation because our legislation removes this anti-age discriminatory provision. You cannot have the shoppies position unless you support our legislation. Yet they voted against our legislation and he was chuffed about it. He boasted about the fact that they prevented our legislation passing the Senate and yet, to get to his policy, he has to have our legislation. This is just crazy. It is an absolute nonsense. This reduces the Labor Party to a laughing stock, which I think they fairly deserve.

The commission then looked particularly at whether or not it would be a good idea to have adult rates at age 18 instead of 21. This is another part of the Labor Party's public position. They said that the removal of junior rates or the introduction of adult rates at 18 years would significantly disemploy young Australians, that is, lead to large scale job losses. The Labor Party has been arguing this proposition. It has been examined. It has been found to be wanting. It has been found to be job destroying. It cannot possibly continue to support that position, and when the Leader of the Opposition gets up today I would like him to now abandon the position which he put publicly not so long ago.

They then go on to say that the current legislative scheme, unless amended by the parliament, amounts to a rebuttable presumption that junior rates be removed from June 2000. This is another key point. I ask the Leader of the Opposition to address this when he gets up because it goes to the heart of his position. The shadow minister has been going around this morning saying that it is a good report and they have done a fine job. That is something, I suppose. Then he says that the Labor Party's approach is a case-by-case approach.
Mr Beazley interjecting—

talk.start.para: —Yes, the commission. That is what they said. Thank you for repeating it. Listen to my point and then see if you have a real answer, instead of just the clumsy, empty rhetoric that we usually hear from you. The point here is that the commission is saying that the legislation as it stands today establishes a presumption that junior rates will go. That is the basic legislative presumption. In fact, if we go to the detail in the commission's report on page 88 at paragraph 3.1.3, they say:

speech.para: Read together, the provisions of the Act approximate a scheme whereby provision for junior rates in awards is deemed prima facie discriminatory on grounds of age, and should not be made, or where made should be removed.
That is the legislative position today.
Mr Beazley interjecting—

talk.start.para: —I heard your confused meanderings this morning.

speech.para: Mr Bevis interjecting—

talk.start.para: —It would be very inconvenient for the member for Brisbane to find himself outside the chamber for an hour.
—Why don't you just listen to a point for a change and see if you can actually answer it?

speech.para: Mr Beazley interjecting—

talk.start.para: —And for the Leader of the Opposition.

—The point I am making is that you say that the issue ought to be dealt with on a case-by-case basis. That is what we say. We say it should be dealt with on a case-by-case basis in the same way that the commission did all the way up until 1993. What paragraph 3.1.3 means is that the commission has its hands tied behind its back. When it looks at the issue on a case-by-case basis, it is constrained by the existing legislation uniformly across any industry when looking at the issue to accept the presumption against junior wage rates.

speech.para: That is the point. The commission cannot look at it on a case-by-case basis when there is a uniform presumption. That is the finding of the commission. That is the whole point, and what we are trying to do is remove that presumption. The test for you and the test for your leader is to stand up and say that you are happy to remove the presumption, because that is basically what we have been saying.

We also say to the commission that they should look at the inclusion of age based junior rates in awards that do not have it. Why do we say that? Because the commission says this is a way of creating jobs, and I reckon that is fair enough. But the Labor Party's answer is, `No, this is telling the commission.' They ought to understand the constitutional position. We are not allowed to tell the commission what to do when it comes to making an award. They always have a discretion. That is the law of this country. That is the constitutional requirement which limits what the parliament can do.

Our legislation simply says to the commission, `You have a discretion. We would like you to exercise that discretion where appropriate—namely, in the discretion of the commission—so as to provide job opportunities for young people.' This is hardly a major difficulty for the commission. The parliament has a view. Our view is that junior rates provide job opportunities for young people, and we say so in our legislation. That does not deny the commission its discretion. As I say, constitutionally we cannot deny their discretion.
Mr Beazley interjecting—

talk.start.para: —Do you understand the Constitution? It is a fairly simple point. This is the slippery tactic that we get demonstrated here by the interjection. You have a simple national responsibility today to young people, and that is not to slip and slide—
—The minister will recognise the chair does not have a responsibility to anybody.
—The chair doesn't have a responsibility to anybody?
—No, in the context of the debate.

—He does have a responsibility, Mr Speaker, and that responsibility is not to slip and slide around this issue, as was just done with the interjection. He has to face up to the simple fact that, on each and every point that we put to the commission, they accepted what we said. The only way in which we can achieve a fair deal for young people in this country is through the support of the legislation that we have currently before the chamber.

speech.para: They also said that if young people are to secure entry level employment and progress to economic self-sufficiency through paid employment they more than ever need to be competitive in the labour market. The Leader of the Opposition ought to support that. They also said junior rates are often a useful bridge to full-time employment, especially for the educationally better qualified. When the Leader of the Opposition stands he should support that. Then the report goes on to say—it makes an obvious point, I suppose—that the government's submissions on the youth labour market and on the adverse consequences for young people of the abolition of junior rates have been broadly adopted and that similar conclusions by bodies such as the Productivity Commission are supported. Of course they are supported.

The evidence on this is completely overwhelming. There is no alternative evidence to the propositions that have been put to the commission. They have spelled it out in black and white. That is another test for the Leader of the Opposition. Compare the test he now faces to the test Tony Blair faced. Tony Blair and the Labour government in the UK faced this issue. They got a recommendation for a junior wage rate so they accepted the basic proposition and, when the amount was put to them, they actually reduced the recommended amount because they were so worried about the job prospects of young people.

The fact is that all the political posturing has now been revealed for what it was—empty rhetoric, bolstered by the ACTU. There is a real urgency in this matter. Employers employing young people today need to know what the rate will be next year. We have had far too much political posturing on this issue for years. The parliament asked for a report; the parliament has got a report. It is absolutely crystal clear. There is no slipping and sliding to be avoided. It is time that this parliament saw fit to do something for the benefit of young people and their job prospects. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: —I intend to rehearse this issue in precisely the same way as did the Minister for Employment, Workplace Relations and Small Business. He started with a bit of history, went to the generality of his industrial relations position, concluded with an assessment of this particular report and invited us to consider his legislation. I intend to respond in precisely the same way. We heard him in silence, and I expect the same as far as my remarks are concerned.

speech.para: Let me first rehearse the history of this and the starting point response of this government. Until they were stupid enough to accept my amendment in the chamber here, they were of course going to introduce the Workplace Relations Legislation Amendment (Youth Employment) Bill 1998 during this afternoon. They will now not have the opportunity to introduce this bill—either that or they have reneged on the agreement to the amendment that we put forward—because this parliament is going to debate this motion for the rest of the afternoon.
Mrs Crosio interjecting—

talk.start.para: —The member for Prospect will excuse herself from the House under the provisions of standing order 304A.

—If you do not debate this motion for the rest of the afternoon you will have ratted on your agreements in this place, so we will be testing you on this. Well might we take vantage of this brief period for delay. Contrast this: those Oakdale miners that were out there during this week have a proposition seeking protection of the justly awarded conditions that they have lost and moneys that are due to them. These issues have been before the government for several years now with a promise for their consideration that is two years old. Have we seen anything? Not one word out of this government, apart from an undertaking for consultation. I will tell you this: if ever there is a proposition that defends workers' wages, if ever there is a proposition to use competency and skills to enhance workers' wages, if ever there is a proposition for workers to be able to defend themselves collectively and advance their interests collectively, this government will defend none of it.

speech.para: The minister says he stands shoulder to shoulder with the workers. Eighteen months ago he said that about people in a similar situation to those at Oakdale. Eighteen months on, it is a very weak shoulder for the workers to rely on. Contrast that delay—when we are actually dealing with decent terms and conditions for working men and women—with the government's performance on this: they get a report, a 330-page report, in the morning. They legislate on that report in the afternoon. This is the deliberation that the community is to be permitted on a 330-page report. I suppose what the minister would say in answer to that is, `Trust me.' This man has been identified as the least trustworthy of ministers in this government, and that is world best practice in untrustworthiness. The least trustworthy minister, courtesy of his last great foray into industrial relations—his utter defeat in the waterfront dispute. The MUA was finally obliged to take on his conspiracy and his manoeuvring to deprive them of their own legislated right—legislated by him—to choose to join a trade union. When it comes to slipping and sliding, this is a bloke who is prepared to conspire to overturn his own legislated arrangements. For him to come in here and challenge us on that particular front is a case of him using an old Stalinist technique, which some very old members of the Left will be very used to around this country: if you are guilty of something, immediately accuse your opponents of the offence and hope they stay on the backfoot and do not expose you. They might in this regard.

Let us now look specifically at the history of this promise. Why was the Industrial Relations Commission considering this? They were considering this because the minister entered into an agreement with the Democrats. He entered into an agreement with the Democrats that he would not move on this issue until he had a report from the IRC. He reneged on that agreement, so this whole thing before us is a massive piece of slipperiness on his part. It is no wonder that, some months ago now, Senator Murray, the Democrat spokesman—given high accolades these days by our political opponents; the honourable people with whom they wish to enter into coalition—spoke about this. What did he say about it? He said:
The rising shrillness of Peter Reith's doctoring of the truth adds to my growing lack of faith in any agreement or assurance entered into by this government.

He should have reflected on that a couple of weeks ago when he started talking to the coalition about GST matters, because that quote is directly related to his experience in dealing with them on this youth wages issue. Then Senator Harradine said that it was now clear to him:
One could not take at face value what this government has said. That is my experience now in respect of certain ministers of this government.

The senator was referring to him. Senator Harradine said that the government's credibility was in tatters and it was a serious matter when at least half of the Senate did not take at face value what this government says.

Again, related to all of this, a completely and utterly untrustworthy government. What is the urgency? The urgency is this: these matters do not come to fruition for another 12 months. This government hoped—until they fouled their tactics—that they were going to oblige us to start the discussion of this three or four hours after production of this report for a problem which will occur 12 months from now. They ask us to accept their bona fides when they want to rush a piece of legislation into this parliament.

When we look at this report we see precisely why it was necessary to get it. The speed with which those opposite want to legislate on it arises because they do not want the community to absorb what the report says before there is an opportunity for the Senate to vote on it, and so that they can continue to erect straw men around their particular proposition and say, sight unseen—or hard to read—that it is endorsed by the IRC. It has not been, of course. The IRC has come to a set of conclusions with which we can agree.
Mr Reith interjecting—

talk.start.para: —The Leader of the House should be aware of the general warning. He will be treated as the Leader of the Opposition would be treated if he exercised the same discourtesy.

—But they are not the conclusions that were drawn by the legislation of this government when it was previously introduced. They are fond of quoting, let me go to the whole paragraph. What the IRC says is:

speech.para: The essence of our report is that none of the identified non-discriminatory alternatives most closely examined by us were feasible. We give our reasons in Chapter 7 in the body of the report. We do not close off the possibility that there are feasible alternatives. We explored the possibility of developing our own proposal but did not persevere. We were already persuaded that in the design of replacement of junior rate classifications no one size fits all. The fit of an alternative is a matter of attention to detail and the merits in particular circumstances. The industrial parties and other interested parties would need to be involved, and that procedure fell outside the statutory limits of our inquiry.

In other words, all those particular propositions in relation to competency based arrangements fell outside their inquiry. They had to give it a `once over lightly' but then came to the conclusion that no one size fits all. We agree.

We agree with the propositions of the IRC as far as this matter is concerned. We agree that the issue of junior wages ought to be considered on a case-by-case basis. We agree that the presumption on changing junior rates should be a presumption that is exercised by those advocating the change. We think there should be no automaticity in that regard. The IRC agrees with us on this matter. We agree that there will need to be change in relation to the legislation, where there is an automatic end. We agree with that proposition. We do not see the urgency, but we agree. That was stated by our spokesman this morning, whose position was lied about in this chamber during question time—but that is just par for the course these days. We pointed out that we agree.

In this chamber there is now only one party that disagrees with the IRC. That is the government, because the proposition of the government is not the IRC's proposition. The proposition of the government is that there will be an automatic extension of junior rates to all areas where it is possible to employ a junior. That is the meaning of their legislation—an automatic extension to all areas where there is the possibility that a person under age can be employed. We say: no; the onus of proof should go the other way. The onus of proof should be that, if you wish to establish a junior wage in a particular area where, potentially, a person with junior wage status may be employed, then you should argue your case. It is your job to establish that case. You do not have it established by a fief and a direction to the IRC to arrive at that conclusion.

The IRC has asked to be empowered on a case-by-case basis. We agree with the IRC. They should be empowered on a case-by-case basis. We will go through your bill, and if you fail that test, old son, we will be moving the appropriate amendments—don't you worry.

talk.start.para: —The Leader of the Opposition knows that the chair is also not planning to fail any test. He will address his remarks through the chair.

—Mr Speaker, that is our response. They are getting a very clear-cut response to the slithering and sliding that the minister has managed in the remarks as far as this is concerned. But we also say this. The poor old IRC had to confess that they did not have the capacity and skills to consider competency based wages. They did not have the capacity to invite all parties in for a discussion on what ought to be done about awarding value on a training outcome. They did not have the capacity to do that.

speech.para: Well, they darn well ought to have. They ought to be given the capacity to do that. Because this is yet another example of how this man, with his slip-sliding deceit, has one agenda—and one agenda only. It is not an agenda for families and it is not an agenda for security in the work force. It is not an agenda for high skills. It is not an agenda for high wages. It is an agenda to deprive workers of rights. If he is faced with a test where he has to defend them, he fails. If he is faced with a test where he has to defend them, he obfuscates, he confuses and he walks away.

He was invited to do that by the Oakdale miners. He said, `Well, we will introduce legislation at some point in time to deal with the sorts of activities that were undertaken by Patrick—with my personal encouragement—during the MUA dispute. We might actually do something about that.' But what about the situation of workers in a circumstance where the company fails? The company may fail in an environment where it is not necessarily the fault of the management, or even if it is the fault of the management, the deprivation of workers rights and entitlements is not a product of the interesting arrangements of the companies to avoid their due obligations by hiding assets. What about those circumstances?

Every other country in the industrialised world protects people in those circumstances—every single one but Australia. If you had an opportunity to stand shoulder to shoulder with a few people around this place, we might see a bit of a defence of that. And when it comes to the issue of competency based wages, it is not that the IRC has difficulty and that they draw attention to that. How about endorsing it? How about supporting it? How about encouraging people to skill themselves? You are the only government in the Western world where expenditure on education and training is actually decreasing. You are the only government in the Western world where expenditure on R&D is actually decreasing—the only one. What sorts of jobs are there going to be in the next century if the people of this nation are not skilled and if our businesses are not encouraged when they are inventive? What sort of future will there be for the security of the employment of our people?

What will you give the young people of this country if you want to impose on the commis sion a presumption—not allowing the commission to conduct its affairs on a case-bycase basis but telling the commission that they will produce a junior wages level if a young person is employed in an area, with no obligation on the employer to argue why that should be so. Are we going to see junior rate policemen? Are we going to see junior rate politicians? Are we going to see junior rate teachers? Are we going to see junior rate soldiers? Are we going to see junior rate airmen? Are we going to see junior rate sailors? Because such a rate is not applied on those at the moment. But you will be obliging the commission to arrive at a few conclusions in that regard without the obligation on the employer to argue. So we throw the challenge back to you lot. How about you support the IRC's report and come up with a piece of legislation on it? (Time expired)

talker.name: Kemp, Dr David, MP
Dr KEMP
talker.role: Education, Training and Youth Affairs; Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Public Service

talk.start.para: —In this debate, the government threw down a challenge to the Labor Party.

speech.para: Mr Beazley interjecting—

talk.start.para: —I remind the Leader of the Opposition of the general warning.
—They asked the Labor Party to tell the Australian people why they are supporting policies which are destroying youth jobs.

speech.para: Mr Beazley interjecting—

talk.start.para: —The Leader of the Opposition will excuse himself from the House.
—I think we have just seen how panicked the Labor Party has been by this resolution of the government. We see that the Leader of the Opposition has now been suspended from the House.
—Mr Speaker, could I ask you to clarify your ruling. Have you suspended the Leader of the Opposition from the House for an hour? If you have, I ask you to reconsider that.
—I believe the Leader of the Opposition would concur that his remarks were inappropriate and, if he is prepared to apologise to the House, I will withdraw that ruling.
—I apologise.
—I thank the Leader of the Opposition, and I call the minister. I remind all members of the existing standing orders.

—We have seen how panicked the Labor Party has been by this resolution of the government and the suspension of standing orders because, if there is one thing the Labor Party does not want to be asked to do, it is to state its policy, because there is no policy on the other side of the House. In this area of youth employment, the Labor Party knows that it has a record of abysmal character, a disgraceful record and a record which has deprived tens of thousands of young Australians of employment opportunities.

speech.para: The Australian people probably ask themselves: why is it that the Labor Party took to itself attitudes and policies when it was in government which were so damaging to youth employment? Why does the Labor Party shut its eyes to the employment plight of so many young Australians? There is a reason for that, and the reason is the nature of the Labor Party itself. Young people are off the radar screen in the Labor Party. The Labor Party's whole focus is on the policies put to it by the trade union movement and the ACTU. In government, it pursued in every area of policy—and particularly in the employment areas—policies which were deeply damaging to the employment prospects of young people.

In 13 years, the Labor Party completely failed to address the changing structure of the Australian economy, which led to many of those low skilled and semiskilled jobs that school leavers used to be able to get, even up to the early 1980s, evaporating. The Labor Party failed to make the adjustments to young people. They tuned in to the ACTU, which says, `Look, we've got an ideological position on employment, and this ideological position is that everybody should be paid according to a particular competency or qualification. That's got to apply to young people regardless of the consequences of that policy for the employment of young people.' And no-one worked more than the member for Hotham, on the other side of the House, when he was secretary of the ACTU to abolish junior wage rates, to get rid of the wage rates which created opportunities for young people.

When the former Prime Minister Paul Keating and the present Leader of the Opposition as employment minister presided over the recession we had to have, we saw a devastation in employment opportunities for young Australians. We saw youth employment soar to record levels of 34 per cent at the time when the Leader of the Opposition was actually employment minister. At the behest of the ACTU, we saw training policies adopted which devastated the apprenticeship system in this country when, in the last year of the Labor government—after 13 years—the number of young people in apprenticeships and traineeships as a proportion of the work force was the lowest for three decades. And why was that the case? Because the Labor Party said that the trade union movement was entitled to have the dominant say in the training system in this country, and the trade union movement and the ACTU were not interested in youth employment. They were interested in continuing to pursue their campaign against junior wage rates. When we came to office, we found that 30 per cent of young people in this country did not have adequate literacy and numeracy skills. After 13 years in government, 30 per cent of young people coming out of school could not read and write properly.

When this government had its first consultations with the business community and asked them why there was a problem in taking young people into employment, it is no wonder that at the top of the agenda was the problem of literacy which had grown up under young people. The Labor Party when in office gave Australian young people the message that if you were not going into university you were not going anywhere. They failed to face up to the fact that 70 per cent of young people leaving school were not going from school to university. There were virtually no opportunities for young people in school to do quality vocational courses that would lead them on to jobs. Because of the ACTU's industrial policies, schools found it almost impossible to work with businesses in their communities to provide proper pathway programs where young people could learn on the job the skills they needed to get jobs when they left school.

So when we came into government in 1996 we found that the Labor policies—the policies that the ACTU had foisted on them—had devastated youth employment. Many young people in this country were desperately disadvantaged by those policies. We found many young people homeless and at risk, dependent on getting good advice to get back into school, to get skills, to learn how to go and get a job—dependent on a program which the Labor Party was abolishing, the one program that worked. Instead, the Labor Party spent in its last year of office $500 million on a program which had a net employment success rate of three per cent and cost $143,000 a net job. It set up a merry-go-round of short-term labour market programs which did not give skills and which demoralised a generation of young Australians.

This government, for the first time, has put into place a comprehensive range of programs which are opening up for young people horizons and opportunities which they were denied for the 13 years that the Labor Party was in office. As a consequence of that, we are now seeing youth unemployment falling. It is still too high, but it is 10 per cent lower than it was when the Leader of the Opposition was employment minister. It is dropping because of the comprehensive range of policies that we have put in place.

Let me just mention some of the most important initiatives of this government. In the first place, we have recognised that the literacy and numeracy skills of young people have to be addressed in the early years of schooling. It is this government—against union opposition; against the opposition of the Labor Party—which has put in place the first national literacy standards against which every child in years 3 and 5 is now being assessed. It is this government that has a commitment from the states and territories that every child leaving primary school will have the basic skills in literacy and numeracy that they are going to need to get a job.

The Australian Education Union has fought this every inch of the way. As a consequence, the Labor Party has never committed itself to sustain and support these policies. In its election education policies it devoted four lines to literacy and numeracy. So it is totally neglecting the foundations on which successful job opportunities for young people are going to be built.

When we turned to the later years of schooling and we looked at the devastated apprenticeship system—the ruins of the apprenticeship system which the Labor Party had left—we realised that a massive rebuilding job had to be done. So, in industry after industry where there were no apprenticeship opportunities and in industries where there had been traditional apprenticeships that had been devastated, we had to have a training system not dominated by the ACTU but delivering the skills that businesses were looking for, that small business needed so they could innovate, so they could improve their productivity, so they could improve their bottom line and so they could create more jobs. That is what this government has put in place.

We now have a new national apprenticeship system, with record numbers of young people in apprenticeships. In December of last year the latest figures were 206,400 young Australians in apprenticeships and traineeships—some 70,000 more than when the Labor Party was in office—a fantastic expansion in opportunities for Australians to get the skills they need for employment. What about those young people coming through the senior years of schooling, that 70 per cent that the Labor Party totally neglected? It is not just our rhetoric that says that; a former member for Sydney, when in this parliament—a member of the Left faction, but an honest person—said that the Labor Party had neglected that aspect of education. He admitted that the Labor Party when in office had neglected that, and it is still neglecting it. In 1995, across Australia there were only some 26,000 young Australians in vocational courses in schools; this year there are some 130,000 young Australians in vocational courses in schools.

We have built a program—the Jobs Pathway program—which is now applied in half of the high schools of Australia, which is making schools proactive in looking out for job opportunities for their school leavers. For the first time, school leavers are moving down these pathways that this government has built, directly from school into jobs. Schools and small businesses across Australia are now working together to make sure that young people in these programs are learning industry recognised skills. Young people can now get certificates which are recognised by industry, which they can build into apprenticeships and which they can take on to diplomas and degrees, if that is what they are minded to do. What we have done is rebuild opportunities and hope for young Australians. In the TAFE system in Australia this government has created 70,000 additional places in the last two years.

Last week ministers from the states and the Commonwealth all met together in the Australian National Training Authority Ministerial Council. A joint resolution was passed by those ministers. Labor ministers in three states and coalition ministers in the other states and territories all agreed on this resolution:

. . . confirming the success of the common efforts of the Commonwealth, States and Territories to deliver a quality training system for Australian industry, Ministers agree to continue to work individually and together to deliver quality training.

That is a historic statement from the ministerial council, agreeing on `the success of the common efforts of the Commonwealth, states and territories' to build for the first time a quality national training system. That is the record of this government over three years. Compare that with the disastrous record of the Labor Party in relation to youth unemployment.

In this debate the government threw down the challenge to the Leader of the Opposition, `Tell us your policies'—and they were not forthcoming. The Labor Party, as it knows, has constantly supported a policy which, as the commission has now laid down authoritatively, will destroy youth jobs. It has no alternatives. It is no good for the Leader of the Opposition to get up in this House and say that the Labor Party will continue to pursue alternatives. There are no alternatives. The only alternatives are the policies that this government is putting forward—and we will create jobs for young Australians. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: —We have just heard from the Minister for Education, Training and Youth Affairs, a minister who has not even read the report. In fact, I suspect that he has not even opened its cover to read the executive summary. But for 15 minutes he did a good job in trying to support the indefensible actions of the Minister for Employment, Workplace Relations and Small Business.

speech.para: The Minister for Employment, Workplace Relations and Small Business has tried, over the last few years, to establish a reputation for being some sort of great political tactician—a person who, through his guile and ideas on industrial relations, has developed a great aura. I would say that his performance today, after watching it, rather ranks with the pinnacle of his strategic coup with the Patrick dispute. That Patrick dispute was months in the making, with the minister and his ministerial colleagues involving themselves in discussions on plans as to how they could bring it off, spending taxpayers money to engage consultants to try to provide ways through it and culminating in one of the greatest botched political exercises in the history of Australian politics.

But today the minister has done himself proud as a tactician. This morning he came into the parliament, thinking he was very clever. Contrary to the normal arrangements, he decided that he would not make a ministerial statement after question time when these matters are normally dealt with. He was going to be very cunning about this. He was going to do it first thing in the morning and then drop the legislation he wanted done into the parliament in the afternoon. That brilliant tactician, the Leader of the House, the minister for workplace relations, then went ashen white in the flurry of the moment when the Leader of the Opposition said, `Okay, we'll have the debate, but none of this 10 minutes either side. Let's have a full-blown debate, with normal standing orders, and let's get into it.'

White faced, the Leader of the House, the minister for workplace relations, said, `Yeah, all right, I'll sign up to that,' and, in the process, just wiped out this morning's brilliant tactic of getting his legislation into the parliament this afternoon—because I can tell you that there are plenty of people on this side of the House only too keen to engage you in debate on the question of junior rates of pay. So that brilliant tactician, the minister for workplace relations, who parades around here as Leader of the House, has just done himself and his government out of his best efforts of this morning.

The Leader of the Opposition made some reference to the comments made by the minister for workplace relations and, indeed, the Prime Minister in trying to express some sympathy with the Oakdale workers and others. As the Leader of the Opposition referred to that undertaking to stand shoulder to shoulder, I thought to myself—and members of the government in their honest moments will know what I mean—that if you were looking for someone in this parliament to stand shoulder to shoulder with in your time of trouble it would not be the minister for workplace relations. Ask the Treasurer; they stand shoulder to shoulder really well!

There are not too many people on the other side of the parliament who would want to stand shoulder to shoulder with the minister for workplace relations—let alone invite the workers at Oakdale to stand shoulder to shoulder with Peter Reith. So not only is he an appalling tactician, as demonstrated by his blunders today, but also his exhortations to people with whom he wants to stand shoulder to shoulder with draw more mirth than anything else.

In no way does the government come to this debate with clean hands. The issue of junior rates of pay has been before this parliament for some time, but let us quickly have a look at what happened in the conduct of this Industrial Relations Commission inquiry. The inquiry was set up as a result of a deal done at that time between the Democrats and the Liberal-National coalition and, as the Leader of the Opposition has pointed out, the Democrats have since gone on the public record to express their concern about how they got doublecrossed by the minister for workplace relations.

But, not content with that, let us just recall what this minister did in the parliament when the commission sought to conduct the inquiry. He introduced into this parliament legislation which made absolutely irrelevant the inquiry which he now heralds. He introduced legislation which would have required the Industrial Relations Commission to ignore the evidence before it, to ignore its own findings and which would have obliged it to insert into every award in this country where a junior person could be employed a junior rate pay scale. It obliged the commission to retain junior rates of pay in every award that currently has them. That piece of legislation was moved by this government in the very month that the Industrial Relations Commission began hearings into the matter.

Why was the commission hearing the matter in the first place? It was hearing it because this government and this minister did a deal to put through legislation that required it to do so. The Industrial Relations Commission did not ask for this job. The minister for workplace relations and this parliament instructed the commission to do it. He voted for a law to tell the commission to do the inquiry but then, when it started the process, he did his best to undermine it. He has made public comments endeavouring to intimidate the commission on this and other matters. He now turns around and says, `I have to report that I can construe to satisfy my needs. So now we should all pick up that report.'

In actual fact the Labor Party does endorse the principal thrust of the recommendations in the report. Unlike the government we do not come to this debate with dirty hands, having tried to undermine the inquiry over the course of the last six months. However, the government even today is continuing to show contempt for that very report and for the commission.

Members of parliament had access to this 350-page report at about half past 10 this morning. If the minister had his way, we would now have in the parliament the bill to actually enforce the government's agenda; that is, the government would have us believe that somewhere between 10.30 this morning and 3.30 this afternoon they sorted out what was their policy. They considered very carefully those 350 pages of the report and wanted to introduce legislation this afternoon to enact their political agenda. The simple fact of life is that this government have given no regard to the report—none whatsoever.

The government have their bill on the Notice Paper, which is the same bill they tried to steamroll the commission with a few months ago. When this minister and other people on the government benches hop up and try to talk positively about this report, we should understand that at no stage have they given the report, its findings, its process or any of the evidence presented before the inquiry the time of day. They have not even bothered to read the report in the six or seven hours since it was available. We just had a minister burbling on about his portfolio because he did not have a damn clue about the report that was before the parliament. I will guarantee that the members sitting opposite now, some of whom might want to get into the debate, have not bothered to read it either.
Let us look at what the report says. There is a sentence in the report that the minister has been fond of quoting in every nook and cranny he can get into today. It says this:
The essence of our report is that none of the identified non-discriminatory alternatives most closely examined by us were feasible.

The minister quoted that again today. In the parliament he said that is proof positive that there is no alternative to junior rates of pay. That is not true; that is not what the commission said. In fact, if you read that sentence properly, they point out that they are talking about only those handful of options which they considered.

The minister refused to accept my invitation during question time, which nearly got me an early exit out of the parliament, that he should read the rest of the paragraph. If he had read the rest of the paragraph to the parliament and been honest with the people of Australia, he would have gone on to note that the commission said this also:
We do not close off the possibility that there are feasible alternatives.
They went on further and said:

We were already persuaded that in the design of replacement of junior rate classifications no one size fits all. The fit of an alternative is a matter of attention to detail and the merits in particular circumstances.

Exactly right. It is that position that the opposition has welcomed; it is that position that the commission put. The minister has been extremely selective in the way in which he sought to go about presenting the findings of this report.

This is what the commission has said, `We had a look at the options that were presented in our inquiry. We did not have the resources or the time to go through the full list. We had a look at some of them. We don't think they will work but we're not going to rule out the others. In fact, we think the solution is in looking at multiple options in different situations—not one size fits all. The way that you progress that is to look at them case-by-case, industry by industry, award by award.' That is precisely the process which should now be followed.

The minister has argued that that is exactly what his bill does. In politics there is a famous saying, `Read my lips.' It is meant to indicate, `I am telling the truth this time. Read my lips and you can see what I am saying.' But when it comes to Peter Reith it is `watch his hands'. It is not what his lips are doing; it is what his hands are doing. Don't listen to what he says, watch what he is doing, because what he says and what he does are two different things.

The simple fact of life is that the bill that this government sought to pursue in the parliament today but managed to torpedo by their own stupidity ties the hands of the Industrial Relations Commission. It does not allow a case-by-case assessment. It will require the industrial commission to retain junior rates scales in every award that presently has them. But it goes further—in typical Peter Reith fashion, one bridge too far—and says that the commission has to insert into every award that does not have a junior rates pay scale such a junior rates pay scale. That is, if there is no junior pay scale in it already, you have to put one in.

The only proviso is contained in the explanatory memorandum to the bill. The minister likes talking about the fact that it says `if it is appropriate'. That is, the commission has to put a new junior pay scale clause in if it is appropriate. Most people hear that and think the commonsense interpretation of `appropriate' is what the government means—not so. In another example of watch his hands rather than his lips, the simple fact is that what is defined in the explanatory memorandum to the bill as `appropriate' is any area in which someone under 21 years of age could be employed. It does not matter whether they are employed there now, if someone under 21 could be employed there, then it is appropriate that there should be junior pay rates in the award. The explanatory memorandum gives a situation in which it is not regarded as appropriate. These are the exact words:
For example, under some awards the employment of people under a certain age is effectively precluded for reasons such as legally imposed age barriers.
They cite restrictions such as the legal driving age or the qualifications for nurses or engineers.

The practical effect of what the government is saying is that, as long as the law allows someone under 21 to do the work, the commission has no choice. We do not intend to sign up to an arrangement that nobbles the commission. For the last four years this government has set about nobbling the commission at every opportunity: it has done it in its 1996 legislation; it will seek to do it in the second wave next week; and it was seeking to do it here today in the legislation it wanted to pursue concerning junior rates of pay. We want to see cases genuinely assessed on their merits individually and without bias.

The Leader of the House seemed to have some difficulty in understanding the position the Labor Party has put today. This morning I made it clear in the debate following the presentation of this matter that we would support changes to the existing law. I said: `Necessarily, to have case-by-case decisions undertaken in which the onus of proof rests with the party wishing to make the change, such a situation would require an alteration to the existing laws.'

We have said we support a change to the existing law. I may have to resort to picture cards to get it across to the Leader of the House, but I will endeavour, in monosyllabic terms, to make it plain even for him. We take the view that in dealing with junior rates of pay from this point on the commission should be free to look at each case on its merits and the onus of proof should rest with that party seeking to alter the status quo in that award. That is plain enough. It is not a complex concept to understand. I would hope that after a day of debate even the Leader of the House could comprehend what that means.

We will not stand for a situation in which this government persist with the tactic they have used from the outset in this debate; that is, to bully the Industrial Relations Commission at every turn, to try to steamroll it with legislation—as they were endeavouring to do this very day—to tie its hands to prevent it from considering matters on its merits, to tie it up in the act so it had no choice. We will not tolerate that nor will we support it. We will, as I said this morning, support changes to the act if the government is willing to do it decently and properly. But we have a minister and a government that understand one way of dealing with this matter—that is, divisive, biased politics. Their whole approach to industrial relations has been to divide Australian workers, one against the other. It is the hallmark of this minister. It is the hallmark of this government. We won't tolerate its further intrusion into junior rates of pay.

talk.start.para: —I would like to congratulate the member for Brisbane, the shadow minister for industrial relations, for at least trying to bring some significant policy questions into this debate. In this he was a complete contrast to his so-called leader, the Leader of the Opposition, who talked about anything but the issues of substance. He talked about Oakdale colliery. He talked about the trustworthiness of my senior minister. He talked about freedom of association in the work force. He talked about research and development at the end of his comments. He talked about everything but junior wage rates and employment policy. The Leader of the Opposition is demonstrating that he has no ideas—and no future, frankly, as a leader. His colleagues are starting to realise that as well.

speech.para: Let us be clear about what this report says. The report says that Australia should retain its system of junior rates. Indeed, we should make our junior rate system more widely available. It says that any move to abolish junior rates would cost young people jobs. It says that the introduction of adult wages at 18 would have significant disemploying effects. The reason why we are seeing so much unhappiness opposite is that that institution that they thought they could rely on, that institution they thought they had in their pockets, has finally discovered the simple truth that junior rates are the way to go.

The commission in its report has said that there is an indisputable relationship between junior rates, their potential abolition and the employment prospects of young people. It says that a discounted pay rate for entry level work continues to be necessary. It says that none of the proposed alternatives to junior rates are feasible. It says that the removal of junior rates, or the introduction of adult rates at 18 years, would significantly disemploy young Australians and lead to large-scale job losses. The report also says that junior rates are often a useful bridge to full-time employment, especially for the educationally better qualified. So this report is a four-square endorsement of the government's approach to the problem of junior wage rates and the employment of young people.

On his travels around Australia, trying to get to know those whom he has abandoned, the Leader of the Opposition would be well advised to take some time to visit the trade union holiday camp at Currawong on Pittwater, which Michael Costa wishes to sell to the transcendental meditation people. What the Leader of the Opposition needs to do above all else is learn to calm down. This opposition leader is running around the country like Pagliacci, the sad clown—bring on the motley, the paint and the powder—but the people know that his heart is not in it. The people know that this Leader of the Opposition, by his conduct today and over the last few weeks, by his constant obsession with dirt and distractions, is losing his grip on the substance of policy leadership.

This government is giving leadership. This government is providing the nation with the policies it needs to address its problems. What we are trying to do this afternoon is to bring the parliament back to the issues of substance, back to the issues which the Australian people want to see debated. I am proud to be part of a government which has brought youth unemployment down to the lowest levels since 1990. Youth unemployment is still too high—we all accept that—but it is lower now than at any time since 1990. Not only that, but the absolute numbers of young unemployed people are at their lowest level since the records were first kept in the late 1970s.

We have brought in a number of policy measures to try to ensure that youth employment rises and youth unemployment falls. We have brought in the principle of mutual obligation so that young people in particular come to recognise that there is a social contract out there—yes, we will do the right thing by them and yes, we will provide them with every assistance to find work but they have to do their part, too. The chief engine, if you like, of mutual obligation is the Work for the Dole program. I am delighted that this government is significantly expanding that program. The numbers will rise to 50,000 in the next financial year. This program is getting results. Thirty-four per cent of participants, young people, in Work for the Dole are going into paid employment, earning wages and learning the habits of work and the work culture which they need if they are to have a decent life. We on this side of the House are on about policy. Members opposite are on about dirt and distraction. It is interesting that Laurie Oakes this week, speaking of an unfortunate incident that befell the Leader of the Opposition last week, said, `The incident can be seen as symbolic.'

talk.start.para: —Order! The honourable member for Fraser on a point of order.
—Sit down, you jerk.
—Order! The honourable member for Batman should be very careful about that sort of provocative interjection. I would ask him to withdraw.
—Mr Deputy Speaker, I withdraw the suggestion that the minister is a jerk.
—No, the honourable member will withdraw unconditionally.
—I withdraw unconditionally the suggestion that the minister is a jerk.
—Order! The honourable member is testing the chair's patience and will not behave like that.

—Mr Deputy Speaker, my point of order is that this is actually a debate about junior wages and the motion which introduced it said that it was to give speakers a chance to outline their policy about junior wages. I had no objection when the minister was straying very widely to talk about youth unemployment, even Work for the Dole, et cetera. We can make political points about that, and that is not a question of standing orders, but this point that he is now getting to is clearly way beyond the reasonable bounds of that debate.

—I am sure that the minister is aware of the motion that put this discussion into place. The honourable member for Fraser acknowledged that he felt the minister had been in order thus far. I cannot quite pre-empt what the minister might do, but I hope that he keeps in mind the spirit of the motion.

—This has been a wide-ranging debate. The Leader of the House ranged widely in his remarks, the Leader of the Opposition ranged extremely widely in his following remarks and I intend to range a little way in my remarks because that is the nature of these sorts of debates.

speech.para: I can understand the shadow minister for employment being in a bit of a foul mood this afternoon. I have a lot of time for the shadow minister for employment. I think he has a fine record of service to the Australian community. I did not much agree with his policies when he was the President of the ACTU, but the fact is that, by his own lights, he did the right thing. Is the shadow minister for employment morally suspect? Of course he is not. Is the shadow minister for employment incompetent? Of course he is not. Nevertheless, it is worth pointing out that, since 1991, the member for Batman has been a shareholder in an ACTU investment company called ACTU Building Pty Ltd, and it has never been declared. His pecuniary interest declarations for both 1996 and 1998 state that he has nil shareholdings in public companies. ACTU Building Pty Ltd's 1998 annual return, lodged with the Australian Securities and Investments Commission on 2 November 1998, shows that the member for Batman still holds 20 per cent of the shares, or one in five shares, in the company. The ACTU Building's 1997 annual return shows the company's activities are as an investor.

talk.start.para: —Mr Deputy Speaker, I rise on a point of order. Quite clearly, the standing orders cannot be in any way interpreted to say that this matter comes within the parameters of the matters we are discussing. The discussion of issues about employment ranges widely but can be acceptable. This is absurdly away from the point.
—The motion under which we are operating states:

interjection.para: That so much of the standing and sessional orders be suspended as would prevent . . . speakers from immediately making a statement for a period not exceeding 10 minutes each, outlining to the House their party's policies relating to junior wage rates as well as their commitment to accepting the recommendations of the inquiry by the Australian Industrial Relations Commission on junior wage rates.

I remind the minister of that. I was cautious in not pulling him up as I thought that the honourable member for Batman had opened himself up to some sort of comment. But the minister might be stretching the broadness of the debate by continuing in this vein.

talk.start.para: —Mr Deputy Speaker, I accept your chastisement in this matter. As I said, I do not wish to imply by any of this that the member for Batman and shadow minister for employment has been morally culpable. I do not wish to imply in any of this that he has made a heinous mistake, that he is disentitled to serve in the parliament, that he should not be a frontbencher—not at all. I simply wish to place on the record that it is easy to make inadvertent errors of this type.

speech.para: When the Leader of the Opposition tries to parade this kind of stunt through the parliament day in and day out, he reveals the fact that he is completely and utterly disqualified from any high office in this country. Frankly, I believe that the member for Batman has had a lot to say recently which is right and true about our country. He has had a lot to say which is right and true about his own party. He has had a lot to say which is right and true about the great traditions in which he wishes to stand and which have been so badly betrayed by so many of his colleagues.

The fact is that his party has sold out the working class. It has gone over to Balmain basketweavers, it has been taken over by middle-class trendies—the dregs of the middle class, as the Leader of the Opposition's father once so famously said—and the member for Batman and others are right to try to take it back. But, if they are serious about trying to take it back, they will support the thrust of this report on junior wages because this is about giving decent young Australians the start they need in life.

What we are witnessing opposite is the slow disintegration of the leadership of the current Leader of the Opposition. His stunts in respect of Senator Heffernan and in respect of the member for Leichhardt are a sign of someone who is seriously losing his grip. I would like to quote something that the Leader of the Opposition said many years ago:
One of the things I want more than anything else is for that man to get peace in his heart.
He was referring to that great of the Labor Party, Mr Arthur Calwell. The Leader of the Opposition said:
There is not enough time left for bitterness in this country, only just enough time for cures.

I think that was a great thing for the Leader of the Opposition to say. I think what we were seeing then from the Leader of the Opposition were high sparks of honour, high sparks of greatness, instincts which could have been created to leadership of real stature. Unfortunately, that has been betrayed in recent days by a man who could do better, by a man who has let himself down, by a man who has let his party down.

We are seeing, as I said, the disintegration of the leadership of the Leader of the Opposition, and we are seeing the Labor Party racked by more division than at any time in recent decades. They oppose Work for the Dole, they oppose the Job Network, they oppose junior wage rates, they tax first and think later, they spend first and think later. The fact is that the Labor Party members opposite, the opposition as a corporate entity, are in serious trouble.

First of all, we had the member for Werriwa trying to come up with decent policy. I do not agree with most of what he said, but it was a serious attempt to come up with the sort of decent policy which could take the Labor Party into the next century. Then we had the member for Melbourne with his book make his effort to come up with decent policy. The member for Melbourne had the decency to admit that what were sneeringly described as `Mac' jobs by so many of his colleagues were just what so many young people needed. `Mac' jobs that are paid at junior rates are just what so many young people need, but these are precisely the jobs that will be taken away from those young people if members opposite are not prepared to support the thrust of the report that has been brought down by the Industrial Relations Commission.

Then most recently we had the member for Batman and shadow minister for employment support the Thomson thesis in that splendid piece of polemic against the entryists who have taken over his party. If John Curtin and Ben Chifley were alive today, they would not be sitting opposite, they would be sitting on this side of the House, as so many of the heirs of Chifley and Curtin are sitting on this side of the House.

This Labor Party has forgotten its beliefs, forgotten its ideals. This is a Labor Party that thinks success is becoming a trade union advocate or being appointed an antidiscrimination commissioner. This is a Labor Party that has forgotten the decent, honest virtues of hard work and that real success comes from creating a business, helping to employ people and making a decent contribution to the Australian economy.

talk.start.para: —That speech by the member for Warringah clearly showed that the attempt to bring on this debate was a stunt, because the government has no substance to contribute to the debate. We have just had the Minister for Employment, Workplace Relations and Small Business and the Minister for Employment Services one after the other make speeches for 15 minutes as they were desperately looking at the clock and running through all the things they could talk about—except youth wages. They were thinking: `Only seven minutes to go, where is another red herring? Only 10 minutes gone, how can I make something else up to talk about?' There was nothing about youth wages because they have nothing to say.

speech.para: Neither of them have read the report; that much is crystal clear. If they had read the report, they would know that there is nothing to say that can link this report to the legislation which the government are proposing to bring in this afternoon. It is a stunt, and I hope the backbench of the government enjoy the fact that this stunt might lead them all to miss their planes this evening. But it was not us who introduced this stunt. We were quite happy to go through the normal processes of the day, but the government introduced this stunt, they mishandled it and the consequences will fall where they may.

Clearly, we could have had a substantive discussion about this matter today under other procedures. For example, if the government had acted competently, we could have had a debate about the report and they could have introduced their legislation. But why did they not want the legislation to be before the House before we discussed the report? Because it would have been crystal clear to everybody that the legislation does not reflect the report.

Unlike the government, the opposition welcomes the report. The government waves the report about but says, `Don't open it.' The government says, `This is a wonderful thing but we will not act on it. We will do something that flies in the face of what this report says.' This report reinforces one thing very clearly—that is, why the parliament was correct to reject the government's attempt to legislate before the report came in. The parliament correctly rejected that legislation. The government should never have introduced it, and it is appropriate that it was rejected.

The opposition supports the view expressed in the report that there should be a case-bycase assessment. We have had some wonderful selective quotation from the report. The Leader of the House quoted some sentences from page ix of the report in question time but somehow forgot to mention some of the other sentences, even after a very forthright invitation from the member for Brisbane to quote the rest. I thought the member for Brisbane was fairly crystal clear that he would have liked the rest of it quoted. He was so crystal clear he nearly got thrown out. The report says:

The essence of our report is that none of the identified non-discriminatory alternatives most closely examined by us were feasible. We give our reasons . . . We do not close off the possibility that there are feasible alternatives.
I didn't hear that part of the quote, did you?

talk.start.para: —No.
—It says:

speech.para: We do not close off the possibility that there are feasible alternatives.
He forgot that bit. It continues:
We explored the possibility . . . but did not persevere. We were already persuaded that in the design of replacement of junior rate classifications no one size fits all.
We agree. Does the government agree? No, you do not. The report continues:
The fit of an alternative is a matter of attention to detail and the merits in particular circumstances.

We agree exactly. Why don't you? Why won't your legislation reflect that report? That is why we were so keen to debate it. We could not believe you were so stupid as to propose this, and we said, `Let's not have a little debate. Let's have a big debate.' If you want to negate the adjournment and have a longer debate, there are all these people sitting behind me who would love to talk about it. How many volunteers have you got? You had two conscripts who did not want to talk about it at all. The report goes on:
The industrial parties and other interested parties would need to be involved and that procedure fell outside the statutory limits of our inquiry.

Exactly! The report says: `Let us have a case- by-case approach.' I say, as the Leader of the Opposition said very passionately, and as the shadow minister for industrial relations also made crystal clear: if the legislation reflects that case-by-case approach which clearly emerged from the executive summary of the report, then we will support it. There will not be a political impasse. There is no need for a crisis, except a political need because the government do not want to change the law. They want an alibi for failing.

The government know that their furphy about the extent to which youth wages affect unemployment is entirely untrue. What would be their excuse for failure if their law passed? They would have to think up a new alibi. They were horrified when their health insurance rebate passed because their excuse for failure in health collapsed. Now they are going to have to live with their tax package. Oh, doesn't that fill their backbench with joy! You can all go out and campaign in all your small businesses for a GST. What they want is an alibi for failure.

But we make it clear: instead of legislating provocatively, instead of legislating by seeking to proscribe that there must be youth wages in every award irrespective of the views of the parties or the merits of the case, if that is what you seek to do, we will not support it. If you legislate to enable the commission to deal on a case-by-case approach, then we have somewhere to go. But if you say, `Everywhere that that's appropriate,' and define `appropriate' as being only those places where the law prescribes that people under 21 cannot work, you will get no support from us nor from the Australian people.

That is not a case-by-case approach. That is proscribing and making mandatory youth wages, even where it does not now apply. I know it is unique. Mr Deputy Speaker, I almost feel like apologising to you for referring to this report. I know that is what we are supposed to be debating, but the last two speakers for the government forgot to mention it. So I just thought I would throw it into the debate and mention this report. I apologise to the members of the government if it causes them shock and grief, but it is supposed to be a debate about that. The commission expresses grave doubts about extending junior rates to the construction industry. It makes it clear that it thinks there is a better approach. Wouldn't that horrify the minister for workplace relations if he had to do that? How would he go about provoking disputes in the construction industry? He has just got all these unemployed rottweilers. Where will he use them if he cannot stir up a blue in the construction industry? If he were to apply this report and its clear intent in the construction industry, he would not be legislating as we believe he intends to legislate. He would be saying that the approach should be application based.

There was a bit of a reaction when the shadow minister for industrial relations made it clear that our view is that, in an application based system, the onus of proof should be on the applicant for change. What a shocking suggestion that the onus of proof should be on the application for change. That is the standard procedure. That is what happens in the Industrial Relations Commission on every application. It has been, I am happy to say, a while since I was an advocate in the commission. There are a lot of workers who are very pleased about the fact that it has been a long time since I was there too, I am quite sure. Nevertheless, even then that was the way the procedure was. If your application failed, the status quo remained. That is what happened. It is not a blank sheet where you both walk in and have a go and they write a new clause for whoever wins. You apply to change the status quo. If the commission rejects your application, the status quo remains.

Of course, all those buffoons who laughed simply proved one thing: they know nothing about the matter. In many instances, that approach will put the onus of proof on the unions. There are junior wage rates in many awards. If you want to take them out, the onus of proof will be on you to do so. If you want to amend them, the onus of proof will be on you to establish the case to amend them. If there are no youth wages such as in the construction industry and you want to put them in, then the onus of proof should be on you to argue the case for why they should be put in. What is remarkable about that, except that you cannot think of what argument the people are going to put? Nor can I.
