Nevertheless, if the law reflects the view that people should have that right to make such an application, that is not a problem for us. But we do not expect that to be the case.

The Leader of the Opposition dealt with this matter very comprehensively. There was a bit of concern that he was passionate about it. I am very proud that my leader was passionate about this. It is a matter that deserves a bit of passion. We are talking about the rights of young Australians. We are talking about how and when people's wages and conditions are determined, and that is a matter about which we care. It is not a desiccated matter which you can come in here and make a few jokes about, as the Minister for Employment Services did, and try to throw a bit of a smokescreen up and talk about anything but the question. It actually matters to people. There are people out there whose lives are going to be affected by the way we do this. It is appropriate to be passionate about it. Everybody on this side of the parliament is very proud that our leader stood up here and made a passionate and firm commitment on this matter, and we support him on that. His heart is in it. What is crystal clear from this debate is that yours is not.

The shadow minister for industrial relations reinforced the detail of the matter, as he did perfectly adequately, I might say, in the response to the report this morning. The reason we have this motion is that the mem ber for Brisbane did so well in the debate this morning the minister did not have the PR line he wanted so he had to come back and have another go. Well done! Got it wrong again. He is almost performing worse as Leader of the House than when we had the member for Gippsland standing in for him last week—and do we all remember that!
Opposition members interjecting—

talk.start.para: —He has not quite got down to that standard yet, but it is a pretty close contest. He has had a bad week, nearly as bad a week as the Treasurer had in question time. Do we remember? We are having a wonderful time in here, but we are not playing games. This is a serious matter and everybody deserves to deal with it seriously and sensibly. I challenge whoever is going to speak next for the government to do one thing—and that will be a change from their predecessors—and that is talk about the report. Make it clear you have read it for a start. Make it clear that you think the case-by-case approach is appropriate. Say that if the legislation does not support a case-by-case approach you will not vote for it. Why don't you try that for a change?

speech.para: This is a debate about our views on youth wages. Our views are clear: we think it should be a case-by-case approach. We support the statement of the commission in paragraph 2 on page ix and we will support a change in the law that facilitates that to take place. If a change in the law does not do that, if it goes as far as you have sought to go before, if it reflects those attempts to mandate an outcome other than on an application based system, we will not support it, and then everybody in Australia will know why we have an impasse. It is because you are looking for a dispute in the area of industrial relations, not for a solution. You are looking for a problem, not for a solution. That is what we expect. That is what we have had every time from this minister.

As the minister for workplace relations, his objectives have been exclusively political. They have not been industrial, they have not been economic; they have been exclusively political. His response to this report procedurally in this parliament, substantially in the legislation he has proposed in the past and the way he has spoken about it today, has been only about the politics of it, not the substance of it. Let us get to the substance. Let us get before the Industrial Relations Commission, deal with it on a case-by-case basis and make sure the legislation that is passed between now and June 2000 when the changes need to be made—not now and tomorrow but now and June 2000—reflect those principles, and we will be able to proceed effectively industrially instead of politically to resolve this matter. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: —At the outset I would like to put the record straight that not one member of the opposition has yet spoken about a policy. This was to be a policy debate, a policy debate about which the Leader of the Opposition said, `Bring it on!' and his face blew up like a big cane toad. He stood there and said, `Bring it on!' and then he said not a word, not one word of policy from the Leader of the Opposition, the shadow minister or now the Leader of Opposition Business in this House. They looked at the clock for 15 minutes and could not wait to scuttle out of here.

speech.para: I will address the substance of what is in this report and how it is damning of the opposition and the stance that they have taken for the last 10 years. Right at the outset though let us look at what the opposition have been about. We know what they stand against. They stand against debt reduction. They have opposed every measure in this House. They stand against tax cuts for average middle income earners. They stand against pension increases.
Opposition members interjecting—

talk.start.para: —For those over there who are shouting, they stand against it. They stand against lower diesel fuel prices. They stand against increases in the family payments.

—Mr Deputy Speaker, my point of order is this: the motion that was passed by the House was to allow people to outline to the House their party's policies relating to junior wages as well as their commitment to accepting the recommendations of the inquiry by the Australian Indus trial Relations Commission on junior rates. The member just speaking is absolutely irrelevant to that and I ask you to bring him back to the matter before the House.
—I thank the honourable member for Watson, but perhaps he has not been listening to the whole debate. I certainly have and it has been very wide ranging. There is no point of order.

—I reiterate: we know what they stand against; we do not know what they stand for. They stand against unfair dismissal. They stand against untimed calls for remote and rural Australia. They stand against youth employment because they opposed the bill put before this House to protect youth jobs by having youth wages protected. They also stand against responsible government. They know what it is they stand against, we know what they stand against, but what do they stand for? On this side we stand for the youth of Australia. We stand for giving them job opportunities.

speech.para: So why was this report by the Australian Industrial Relations Commission on junior rates actually necessary? It goes back to 1993, as the Minister for Employment, Workplace Relations and Small Business said. At that time the Keating-Beazley government put in place a statutory scheme which prima facie declared junior rates to be discriminatory and not to be made or, when made, to be removed. When you think about that, where is the economic sense in it? There is none. Where is the statement that this is about creating jobs or creating assistance for anybody? There is none.

But many of us have forgotten that back in those dark days of the early 1990s political correctness was the phrase that came across everybody's lips. It was a phrase that the thought police were on the lookout for. Political correctness is what led to this disgusting piece of legislation, which has put into the hands of those opposite—that they do not want removed—the chances of young people getting employment in this nation. Political correctness—we wanted to see it wiped off the face of the earth and see some commonsense in this place. Commonsense is not something those opposite are too much endowed with.

Let us go to the report itself. Let us turn to its terms of reference. If you want to know what the report is about, what it was designed to do, then let us look at the terms of reference as a basis from which to start. The commission was to report on junior rates of pay. Point (2) states:
The report must include assessments of:
(a) whether it is desirable to replace junior rates with non-discriminatory alternatives;

You would think that if it has to do that someone would have to put up some alternatives for it to measure against. I think everyone accepts that. Some people did put some alternatives. The people who put them up were: the Construction, Forestry, Mining and Energy Union; the shoppies' union; the ACTU, of which some of those opposite obviously were the boss and probably wrote half of their submission; ACOSS, the Australian Council of Social Service; the Queensland government; and the Amalgamated Metal Workers Union. They all put up proposals to be evaluated. We all know that everybody opposite is a member of a union, so therefore everybody opposite supports one or more of the proposals that were put forward before the commission. I think that is a pretty reasonable assertion to make. So an independent body has assessed whether or not these measures, which are not discriminatory alternatives, could in fact replace junior wage rates without hurting employment opportunities.
Did they do that? Let us go straight to the guts of this in the summary page. Point 2 says:
The essence of our report is that none of the identified non-discriminatory alternatives most closely examined by us were feasible.

Not the CMFEU, not ACOSS, not the Queensland government, not one of them. What did the Leader of the Opposition, Mr Beazley, say about that when he came in here? Nothing. He puffed himself up like a bullfrog as he has been doing time and time again today. In fact, he has undermined this House so badly today that, on two separate occasions, he has been forced to apologise to the Speaker simply to save his backside from being kicked out of this place. They are the sorts of standards that he has had to uphold. Why? Because, right now, the Leader of the Opposition is under so much pressure from those sitting behind him that he has to come in here with confected indignation and give himself a blood pressure problem so that those opposite will somehow support him for another week or two.

talk.start.para: —Order! The honourable member for Longman will resume his seat. I call the honourable member for Paterson on a point of order.

—Like you, Mr Deputy Speaker, I have listened to the whole of this debate, and I would say that now the member is being extremely wide ranging. He is not addressing the debate. The important thing is that he is wasting an enormous opportunity to tell us what the policies of his party are in relation to youth wages.

—You are not going to debate the point of order. Resume your seat. I certainly do agree that, while it has been a very wide-ranging debate, we should try to concentrate a little more on the direct substance of it.

—Not a problem, Mr Deputy Speaker. I understand his sensitivity. He obviously knows which faction he is in, so he has to put his plug up. He invites me to say what our policy is. We put our policy into this parliament; you rejected it. It was set aside; it is now coming back before this parliament. We had a policy that went to the people in 1996. We told them that we support youth wages. We support a discriminatory—positively discriminatory, I might add—piece of legislation which will allow people to be able to get a start in life—something that the Labor Party is not interested in. There is any number of productivity reports and other reports that fully support that—I will turn to those shortly. Those opposite are the ones who stand condemned.

speech.para: The member for Brisbane, who is the shadow minister on this particular subject, and the Leader of the Opposition have both stood here today and misled this House by saying that the government will insist that the Industrial Relations Commission must—I repeat, must—ensure that any industry which does not have junior wage rates must legislate for them. That is incorrect. That is a furphy, in military terms. It is a beat-up. It has no basis of fact whatsoever.

The point that we are making here is that there are many industries. You have pointed out the construction industry. The member for Bowman, who I debate with every Friday afternoon on radio up in Brisbane, said last week, `If you had the choice of an 18-year-old and a 30-year-old who could both do the same job, why shouldn't they get the same pay?' In the construction industry, if they could get the same pay, why aren't there any 18-year-olds? It is because people choose the 30-year-old. They choose the person who has more experience and more stability. You do not seem to understand that. You are condemned by the fact that there are so few juniors working in the construction industry. There should be more people in the construction industry. There are more jobs to be created in the construction industry, and we have the legislation which we have already had before this place and which we will reintroduce into this place. What we want to hear and what the public wants to hear is where you stand. We have not yet had one constructive point about what the Labor Party stands for.

I turn back to the 1998 election. When this issue was brought up, what did the Labor Party say? They said, `We want to wait for the Productivity Commission.' You would have got into government. You would have had two weeks in which to give some sort of a report to the commission. If that is not legislation or policy on the run, I do not know what is. The fact is that you do not know where you stand on this because you are condemned. You are locked in by the unions who have all put up their proposals. They have all been knocked on the head and so you are caught between the devil and the deep blue sea.

talk.start.para: —Actually, the chair is not caught anywhere. You might address your remarks through the chair.

—I agree, Mr Deputy Speaker; you would be far from caught on any occasion. Those opposite are in fact caught between the devil and the deep blue sea because, on one hand, they have the unions trying to carry on and tell them that we want to get rid of youth wages, but they know in reality that it is going to destroy 200,000-odd jobs in the retail sector. It is going to ensure that people do not get jobs in the construction industry and many other industries. There is any amount of information in this report and in others which actually points to that. I turn to page 163 of this report, which refers to the Productivity Commission. Point 5.6.8 states:

speech.para: That study, "Youth wages and employment" , examined numerous minimum wage studies particularly those carried out overseas and concluded that . . .

para.inline: Many of the studies that argue for a limited effect on employment are focused on the short run . . .

speech.para: Isn't that typical of the opposition? It continues:

para.inline: . . . but it is important to also consider the longer run implications of minimum wages. There are substantial lags in the adjustment process and it takes time for capital-labour substitution to take effect. Finally, studies that focus on minimum wages—set at low levels and affecting only a small proportion of the workforce—are likely to understate significantly the employment effects of wage changes affecting much larger groups.

speech.para: In 1995, there was a survey of employees from 1,800 workplaces. It states:

para.inline: . . . the balance of evidence presented here suggests that a large increase in relative wages of teenagers could be expected to have a negative impact on their employment.

speech.para: How much more evidence do you need? I turn to a further conclusion, which says:

para.inline: The purpose of the study was to examine the determinations of youth employment in order to shed light on the possible implications of abolishing junior rates of pay in State and Federal awards. To the extent that replacing such awards with non-discriminatory alternatives—

speech.para: which have all been examined by the commission and have been found to be wanting—

para.inline: would lead to an increase in youth wages, the results of this analysis would suggest quite strongly that there would be a more than proportional reduction in youth employment.

speech.para: Everything points to the fact that what you have been supporting for 10 years would, in fact, lead to greater youth unemployment. Ten years ago this was floated. We have had any number of state governments put up propositions and yet not one of them has been able to come to a conclusion.

If you want to look overseas, look to the UK. The Leader of the Opposition just loves talking about Prime Minister Blair and what a great bloke he is, saying, `There's someone you can follow.' In the UK the Low Pay Commission was established by the Blair government.

talk.start.para: —Mr Deputy Speaker, I raise a point of order. This is supposed to be about outlining to the House the positions of each of the parties.
—What is your point of order?

—I do not think the speaker is being relevant, Mr Deputy Speaker. He is not outlining his party's position; he is talking about the international experience. I think he should be relevant to the debate.

—The honourable member for Longman will continue his remarks. I think it has been quite obvious throughout this debate that espousing one's own policies has certainly taken on the atmosphere of looking at the other side's policies as well.

—As I said, in the UK the Blair government went further than just accepting the recommendations of the Low Pay Commission; they actually recommended a minimum junior rate but then proceeded, by their own motion, to further discount that recommended minimum out of a concern for the youth labour market. The Labour Party of Great Britain is concerned about youth jobs. The Labor Party, those opposite, simply are not. Ireland followed with the Irish National Minimum Wage Commission and maintained the youth wages.

speech.para: Let us turn to other Labor governments here who could also do something about it. Every state, every territory, has it within its power today—and always has—to legislate to remove junior base wages. Has Peter Beattie in Queensland? Has Carr in New South Wales? No. Does Bacon in Tasmania? No. They hide behind their rhetoric as Beazley, the Leader of the Opposition, hid behind his today. But they know in their heart of hearts it will do one thing and one thing alone—that is, destroy jobs. When they get out from behind the unions that continually throw up these stupid ideas—which have been proven to be so by the commission—and come up with decent policy such as the policy which this minister has put before this House, we will not only see junior wages protected, we will see youth employment in this country protected so that it can grow into the future.

talk.start.para: —I rise to speak in what I consider to be a very sad debate. I say that because this afternoon the Australian Industrial Relations Commission challenged the Australian community—and, more importantly, this House—to consider, in a non-political and constructive way, where we go on one of the most complex issues confronting the Australian community at the moment. It does not just relate to the issue of youth unemployment, it also relates to a serious problem on the employment front in general. It is in that context I am pleased to say that not only has the Australian Labor Party's opposition welcomed the Industrial Relations Commission report but, more importantly, it has left the door open for us to proceed with a constructive debate with the government with a view to trying to ensure that we all, as a community, face up to the challenges laid down by the Industrial Relations Commission in its report today.

speech.para: That to me is exceptionally important. I am pleased to say that we on this side of the House do not consider that we have all the solutions. We have made progress in the past, but we must also learn from some of our mistakes in the past. That is why it was the parliament itself that asked the Australian Industrial Relations Commission to consider what is a broad ranging debate on the issue of junior rates. The commission has, in a non-ideological way, brought forward a report which challenges us all. The report challenges us all because it does not endorse the position of the government, nor does it endorse the traditional position of the union movement and nor does it endorse the traditional position of the Australian Labor Party. Debate is about us facing up to the fact that we have to endeavour to take on board the ideas and the suggestions of the Industrial Relations Commission and try and work out—for the sake of our young people, for the future of this nation—how we create a highly skilled work force, involve our young people and give their mothers and fathers some hope for the future.

Let us go to the report of the Industrial Relations Commission. Why is this government so afraid of allowing the Australian community to take on board a report which is not only a report of substance but one prepared over six months? It is a report that encouraged all in the community, irrespective of whether they are union representatives, community representatives, employer representatives or representatives of political parties, to put forward their ideas, on the basis of which, the commission would bring forward a report which laid out the ideas and, in essence, said, `It is now our responsibility to consider an application, by whatever party the Australian community so chooses, to go forward and determine these matters on merit.'

I agree with the Industrial Relations Commission. The report ought to be a catalyst for the resolution of major political and policy issues in the Australian community today. It ought not be the intention of this government—as it was this afternoon—to close off debate in a knee-jerk, short-term political response; a debate which the Australian community expects to go on with a view to trying to put in place decent solutions.

I also want to say in considering the report of the Industrial Relations Commission that no jobs will be destroyed. The Industrial Relations Commission can proceed to consider the future of junior rates on the basis of merit in the current legislative framework. There is nothing to stop the Industrial Relations Commission from considering an application as to where we go on a broad range of suggestions that are laid out in the report. But I suppose from the government's point of view it is all about excuses: excuses from a government that is treading water on the issue of unemployment, excuses from a government that is not serious about the issue of unemployment.

I want to touch on a few issues. We currently have unemployment in the order of 7½ per cent. If this government was serious not only about reducing youth unemployment but also about reducing unemployment in general, I would have thought that it would have put before the House a budget strategy to ensure that the level of unemployment in 12 months time was reduced instead of remaining the same. I would have thought that the government would be consumed with trying to ensure that the reduction in unemployment in the last three years was related more to jobs growth than to a fall-off in the participation rate. I would have thought that the government would have some ideas about how we overcome the fact that youth unemployment in Australia still is over 23 per cent and, more importantly, that 70,000 young unemployed people in Australia do not have a job, do not have a training opportunity and do not have any hope for the future.

But, when you look at the nature of the seats that this government represents, it is not a government that is actually concerned with these issues. Let us go, for example, to the Prime Minister's seat in the lower northern Sydney area. It is interesting that, with respect to his constituency, we are talking about a youth unemployment rate of 2.1 per cent against a national youth unemployment rate of over 23 per cent. I really wish some of these people were prepared to debate these issues in a constructive way and, in doing so, visit some suburbs and regions such as Canterbury-Bankstown, Fairfield-Liverpool, Hunter, Newcastle, Richmond-Tweed and the mid-north coast of New South Wales, the western districts of Victoria, the Mallee, Gippsland, the outer north and west of Brisbane and northern Adelaide where youth unemployment is normally way above the national average of 20 per cent. That is the crux of the debate. If you were actually concerned about the plight of those young people and the worries of their parents in those suburbs and regions, then you would not be seeking this afternoon to shut off the debate in a knee-jerk reaction to what is a constructive report by the Australian Industrial Relations Commission.

That takes me to the thrust of the report by the Industrial Relations Commission. It says to all of us, `Stop and consider this issue in a constructive way.' It says in essence that, `Having prepared this report, our responsibility is to now consider, industry by industry on the basis of test cases, what is the appropriate framework for the employment of young people throughout Australian industry in the future.' That is what it says. It is a report; it is not a decision. The issues have not been resolved—because we, this national parliament, did not ask the Australian Industrial Relations Commission to resolve the issue of whether juniors, be it on the basis of age or on the basis of experience of work, be paid an appropriate rate of pay. We asked the Industrial Relations Commission to consider the arguments and then work out how it might, with the support of this parliament, go forward to consider these issues in a constructive way with a view to maximising employment amongst the young people and, more importantly, where a case is established in some industries—be it hospitality, retail or perhaps even in some sections of the building and construction industry—in return for accepting a lower rate of pay than adults, those young people be guaranteed some quality training which guarantees them a better career opportunity in the future.

That is what the debate is about. Our young people—be they employed or unemployed at the moment—know their responsibilities. But they are also pointing the finger at both sides of this parliament to ensure that we throw the rhetoric out the door, walk away from our traditional ontological position and allow the commission to now consider these matters on merit. I fully support that position. That is the position of the Australian Labor Party and that is the position that we are putting forward to the Australian community at the moment.

Another exceptionally important point this parliament has to acknowledge is that in considering an application for change—be it in the retail industry, the hospitality industry or the building and construction industry—the burden of proof for change should be on those proposing change, whether it be the government or the industrial parties. That is what the commission said today. There is a framework to go forward. If you want to argue for a change in a given industry, then it is up to you—the government or the industrial parties—to make out a case and to ask that the Industrial Relations Commission consider your case on merit.

I am not afraid of such a debate. That is that nature of the political processes. It is the environment in which I grew up for 20 years as a trade union official, representing workers all around Australia. In order to win the support of the Industrial Relations Commission for an argument I put forward, I had to have merit on my side. But this afternoon we have an endeavour by this government to strangle the independent Industrial Relations Commission that this parliament asked to prepare a report to be debated in the parliament, in the Australian community, in the churches and the community organisations and by the mums and dads and the industrial parties.

Let the debate go on. It will be 12 months before we run into problems with the application of the current act. The Industrial Relations Commissioner has told the minister in no uncertain terms, `Enough is enough. Stand back and allow us to consider these matters on merit. Stand back and allow us to ensure that the industrial parties and the government of the day are forced to put up or shut up.' They either have a case or they do not have a case. I am not afraid of the debate, the Australian community is not afraid of the debate and, more importantly, Australia's 70,000 young unemployed and their mothers and fathers are not afraid of the debate. Those unemployed people who are, unfortunately, more and more concentrated in particular suburbs and regions expect more of this political debate.

We have a way forward on the issue of unemployment. It is about quality training—a new and a better deal for the unemployed. It is about giving incentives to employers and to young people to get them back to work. It is about a national skills strategy that actually rewards young people if they are in some instances required to accept lower rates of pay than adults. It is about fair and flexible workplaces. It is about addressing the new geography of the labour market. It is about ensuring—as is the intent of the Australian Industrial Relations Commission today—that we as a community cope with change by assisting people in making the necessary transitions from school to work or, in some instances, from one job to unemployment and back to work.

I simply adopt this approach: this afternoon we should be renewing our commitment to a constructive debate in this parliament about ensuring that we as a community face up to our responsibilities to do something to create even better training and employment opportunities, with the assistance of the independent Industrial Relations Commission, to assist our unemployed.
Debate interrupted.

talk.start.para: —Order! It being 5.30 p.m., I propose the question:

interjection.para: That the House do now adjourn.

talk.start.para: —On the adjournment tonight it is appropriate, with the Minister for Employment Services at the table, to speak on some of the policies that the government claim they have in the area of employment services. The minister comes in here and parrots in question time and in every debate that is going the Work for the Dole scheme. But what the minister has not done is come into this place and had a full debate on the evaluation done by the Department of Employment, Workplace Relations and Small Business, which he released at the end of last month. One of the important suggestions that was in the evaluation by his own department was that the program's name should be changed from Work for the Dole to such things as `Work for the Future' or a scheme called `Volunteers for Australia'. It is understandable that the government, with their penchant for penalising the victims of certain things in Australian society, continue to champion the name Work for the Dole. In an article in the West Australian , it is stated that a spokesperson for the Minister for Employment Services said that the Prime Minister is keen on the name Work for the Dole. Shame on you, Prime Minister. The only reason that anybody would suggest that the name Work for the Dole was appropriate is that it indicates in some way a malevolence on the part of those proposers that this scheme should be seen as being some form of punishment.

speech.para: As I have said all along, we on this side of the House could agree with an employment program that has some basis of mutual obligation if it were in fact fair dinkum and if it had an element of training way beyond what is proposed by the Work for the Dole scheme. If we compare the type of Work for the Dole scheme that the government has with the programs that were produced under Labor governments, the element that is missing from Work for the Dole is not the work experience—and everybody understands the value of that. It is not the work experience that there is any argument about; it is the fact that there is no add-on. There is no value adding in the scheme; there is no adding that gives proper training to the participants. There is no training that then gives skills that can be transferred to other employment. The real problem with the way that the debate about this program has gone is that it is seen to be one of those subjects where it is us and them, that the government has some sort of virtue on the basis of the program that they have in place and that any programs that we proposed previously were wrong.

If we look at the evaluation produced by the department and we look at the outcomes of the Work for the Dole scheme, it is not any better than the programs that Labor had in place; in fact, in the cases of most other programs Labor governments had better levels of positive outcomes. If we are going to have debates about giving opportunities to young Australians to get employment and we are going to have the sorts of discussions that we are having now on youth wages, we have to be fair dinkum. We have to look at the alternatives, and we have to not go into debates that are just based on ideology. Just as we have seen in the discussion that we had this afternoon—when there was a proper discussion of what the commission has actually said in its report—we should be looking at ways in which to encourage young people into employment, and youth wages should not be seen as the problem.

I have said, and the minister knows, that I would be willing to give support for an employment program based on the notions they have in place with their so-called Work for the Dole if it were improved. I dispute the notion that the minister put—I think it was in the last sitting week—when he criticised the Brisbane City Council's attitude to this program. He did not recognise that the Brisbane City Council would support an employment program where there was mutual obligation and where government was offering more than just work experience. And that is the case. The notion of mutual obligation being something that only the government has championed is nonsense. We need to have a proper debate on what is required for governments to offer young people to give them a chance to have positive outcomes from any employment programs offered by the government. That is what the young people of Australia are looking for; young people of Australia are looking for opportunities. They produce positive work, and they should be given opportunities. (Time expired)

subdebateinfo.title: Suspension of Standing and Sessional Orders

subdebate.1.para: Motion (by Mr Reith)—by leave—proposed:
That so much of the standing and sessional orders be suspended as would prevent the routine of business for the remainder of this sitting being as follows without any interruption:
(1) Notice No. 5, government business, being called on and proceeded with forthwith;

(2) At the conclusion of the Minister's second reading speech relating to the Workplace Relations Legislation Amendment (Youth Employment) Bill 1998 [No. 2], the debate being immediately adjourned, and the resumption of the debate being made an order of the day for the next sitting; and
(3) The question—That the House do now adjourn—being then put immediately, without amendment or debate.

talk.start.para: —The question is that the motion be agreed to. All those of that opinion say aye—

—Hang on, I wish to speak to the motion. Mr Speaker, we oppose this motion. This is a suspension vote where there may be two speakers, one in opposition—and away I go. Mr Speaker, I absolutely oppose this motion. This is a product of `completely wreck' tactics.
—The Leader of the Opposition does not—
—He has to move that I be not further heard.
—The Leader of the Opposition did not have the call.

interjection.para: Opposition members interjecting—

talk.start.para: —I was putting the question.

—Mr Speaker, I raise a point of order. My point of order, Mr Speaker, is that you put the question, and upon your putting the question I put, `That the question be put.' That was the motion before the chair. Under the procedures of the House, once the motion has been put and the motion `That the motion be put' has been moved by, in this case, the Leader of the House, under the standing orders there is no alternative course of action available to the Speaker and that question must be put without delay, without interruption. On that basis, Mr Speaker, that vote should now be conducted.

—Mr Speaker, on the point of order: there is a provision in standing orders for the suspension of standing orders, that is true, and we would not dispute it. There is a specific set of standing orders associated with that. It says that the mover of that particular proposition, should he seek to exercise it, has 10 minutes, the seconder has five, and the alternative point of view has 10 minutes to be put.

interjection.para: I assume that there was nobody on the other side jumping to speak; I was on my feet. When you call a particular proposition, Mr Speaker, there is an obligation upon you to follow through with those standing orders and call the people who were entitled to speak under it until the debate is concluded according to standing orders. I was on my feet, Mr Speaker, as you started the process of putting the question—

talk.start.para: —That is quite right.

—Which is, when the person who has moved or spoken to a motion sits down, you read the motion that is before the House and then people get up to speak to that motion. I was on my scrapers to do precisely that, there still being time under the 25-minute requirement associated with a suspension of standing orders for me to be able to put a case against the suspension.

interjection.para: Mr Speaker, I would argue that I was on my feet, I was in a position to be recognised and you did recognise me, after seeing that I was on my feet, and I began to speak on the basis of your recognition of me. Then the Leader of the House came in. He is not entitled to put a motion that the motion be put. All he can do in those circumstances is move that I be not further heard and then, at some subsequent time, he can do so. But he has not done it up to this point. Therefore, Mr Speaker, I was legitimately on my feet and I am entitled to the call to the completion of my remarks.

talk.start.para: —Mr Speaker, on the point of order: the standing orders on this are quite clear. Just to explain it to the former Leader of the House, we regularly have situations where motions are put and then the effective gag motion is that the member be not further heard. That is what usually happens. The reason that that happens in that way is that you cannot put the procedural motion—namely, that the question be put—until the question has been moved and seconded and the question before the chair has been stated by the chair.

interjection.para: Once it has been stated by the chair, then the procedural motion that the question be put can be moved at any time either prior to a member standing and speaking or, alternatively, in the situation where a member has the call. In this particular case, the member had the call but that is irrelevant.
Opposition members interjecting—

talk.start.para: —Members on my left seem to have forgotten, including the member for Prospect, that there has been a general warning issued to the House.

—The simple point is that, once you have stated the question, any member may move under the standing orders that the question be put. That was the motion put to you; I put it to you. Under the standing orders there is no other course of action available to the chair but to put that question to the ballot. That is what you were doing. I put it to you, Mr Speaker, you have no choice but to proceed accordingly and conduct that ballot.

—Mr Speaker, on the point of order: whatever the convention of the House is, the standing orders are clear: a motion to suspend standing orders must be moved and seconded. That is what the standing orders say.

interjection.para: It is different from another motion that is there to be moved by a minister. A minister can move any motion before this House without a seconder but not the suspension of standing orders, according to the standing orders. Therefore, for a motion such as that—namely, that the motion be put—to be legitimately before you, it will have had to have been appropriately seconded. If the minister is going to be in a situation to gag me, the only motion that he could move on me was a motion that I be no longer heard, not a motion that the motion be put. Therefore, Mr Speaker, I should still be on my scrapers addressing this House on this vital matter and I should still have a few minutes left of my time in order to be able to do it.

talk.start.para: —If I can rule on the point of order.
—Mr Speaker—

interjection.para: Honourable members interjecting—

talk.start.para: —I am getting a little tired of having to remind members of the conventions of the parliament. Is the Leader of the House seeking to make a comment on the point of order?
—Mr Speaker, on the point of order, just to put the matter absolutely beyond doubt, I refer you to standing order 93, which makes the point:

interjection.para: After any question has been proposed from the Chair—
which you did—
either in the House or in the Main Committee, a motion may be made by any Member, rising in his or her place, and without notice, and whether any other Member is addressing the Chair or not—
which is the point that the Leader of the Opposition failed to appreciate—
"That the question be now put", and such motion shall be put forthwith without amendment or debate.
That is exactly the point I have made, and I invite you to proceed accordingly.

talk.start.para: —I will rule on the point of order. The House needs to bear in mind that the House has spent much of this afternoon debating a motion moved by the minister that standing orders be suspended, which was, by the way, not seconded. I have, as the minister said, proposed the question that the motion be agreed to and I now put that question.

interjection.para: Question put: That the motion (Mr Reith's) be agreed to.
The House divided. [6.00 p.m.]
(Mr Speaker—Mr Neil Andrew)
Voting details are recorded in the Votes and Proceedings .
Question so resolved in the affirmative.

debateinfo.title: WORKPLACE RELATIONS LEGISLATION AMENDMENT (YOUTH EMPLOYMENT) BILL 1998 [No. 2]

subdebate.1.para: Bill presented by Mr Reith, and read a first time.

talk.start.para: —Mr Speaker, I raise a point of order.

—The member for Calwell does not have the call. I have an obligation to point out to him that the resolution as carried by an absolute majority allows the Leader of the House to present this bill without interruption. There is no provision for interruption. I cannot recognise the member for Calwell and I call the Leader of the House.
—I move:

speech.para: That the bill be now read a second time.

The Workplace Relations Legislation Amendment (Youth Employment) Bill 1998 [No. 2] will amend the Workplace Relations Act 1996 and the Workplace Relations and Other Legislation Amendment Act 1996 to remove the uncertainty surrounding junior rates of pay by exempting junior rates, on a permanent basis, from the age discrimination provisions of those acts. The bill will also amend the principal object of the Workplace Relations Act to include within its scope the protection of young people's competitive position in the labour market, the promotion of youth employment and the reduction of youth unemployment, and these will also be objects to which the Australian Industrial Relations Commission must have regard in making and varying awards. In particular, the bill will require the commission to support youth employment by ensuring that, where appropriate, awards that apply to work that is or may be performed by young people include junior rates of pay.

This bill is identical to the Workplace Relations Legislation Amendment (Youth Employment) Bill 1998 which was introduced in the House of Representatives on 26 November 1998, passed by the House of Representatives on 10 February 1999 but rejected by the Senate on 8 March 1999. Members who are concerned about the welfare of the young employed and of the young unemployed should match that concern with support for this bill.

The bill is about supporting and enhancing the job prospects of young people. It does this by maintaining the existing system of junior rates and by making junior rates more widely available. The bill is not about cutting junior rates; it is about protecting jobs for young people by protecting junior rates. Junior rates have been a feature of the wages system in Australia since early this century. Over 400,000 young people under 21 are paid junior wages—this represents over half of all employed young people.

But junior rates are under threat. Under the existing provisions of the Workplace Relations Act, the continuation of junior rates in awards cannot be guaranteed after 22 June 2000. Until then, junior rates in all awards are exempted from the provisions of the anti-age discrimination requirements of the Workplace Relations Act. But this across-the-board exemption that protects junior rates expires on 22 June 2000.

Because of the importance of junior rates for getting young people into jobs, this government's preferred position has always been that junior rates should be allowed to continue indefinitely—a position reflected in the Workplace Relations and Other Legislation Amendment Bill 1996 as originally introduced into this parliament. However, following discussions with the Australian Democrats when the bill was before the Senate, the government agreed, as a temporary measure, to limit the exemption to a further three years and to put in place a mechanism for the commission to review the feasibility of abolishing junior rates of pay. This reflected a compromise position only agreed to by the government as a way of avoiding the legislated removal of junior wages. The coalition agreed to the review on the clear understanding that our policy would continue to be for the retention of junior rates and that we would seek a mandate for this legislation at the next election. We are now seeking to implement that mandate.

It is also the government's view that, in order to provide support for youth employment, junior rates should be more widely available. The government's support for the retention and extension of junior rates was articulated in a ministerial discussion paper that I issued in June last year entitled `Protecting job opportunities for young people'. More importantly, it was a policy specified in black and white in the coalition's pre-election workplace relations policy, `More Jobs Better Pay', and publicly debated during the recent election campaign. That policy has now been endorsed by the Australian electorate. This bill gives effect to that policy.

Under the provisions of the bill, the way in which junior rates would be introduced into any particular award would be a matter for the commission. It would be open to the commission to include transitional `grandfathering' provisions similar to the way the commission has dealt with transitional issues of this nature in the past, as evidenced by the way it dealt with the conversion of paid rates awards to minimum rates awards. I emphasise again that this bill is not about cutting the wages of existing employees.

A number of members who spoke against the initial bill said that the bill should not have been brought forward until after the tabling of the commission's report on junior rates. Their initial opposition to the bill was determined by timing and process issues rather than by the merits of the bill itself. This perceived difficulty has been resolved. I have tabled the commission's report. The parliament can now proceed to assess the youth employment bill on its merits. I hope the opposition appreciates—as a result of today's handling of this legislation and the report—that this government is very determined to see this matter settled once and for all.

In summary, the commission's report finds that junior rates are important for getting young people into jobs, that none of the alternatives put to the inquiry are feasible replacements for junior rates, that any move to abolish junior rates would cost young people jobs, and that the introduction of adult wages at 18 would have significant disemploying effects. The report of the commission adds to the case in favour of junior rates. It is a case that is already overwhelming. Any move to abolish junior rates would be a highly irresponsible move, particularly given the delicate labour market situation that confronts young people.

The bill will also address the concern expressed in the commission's report that some aspects of the anti-age discrimination provisions of the Workplace Relations Act are ambiguous and vague. The report suggests that these ambiguities will eventually have to be addressed in parliament, in the commission or in the court. We agree that it is essential to remove any uncertainty about how the anti-age discrimination requirements of the Workplace Relations Act apply to junior rates.

Any uncertainty about junior rates does not create a stable environment for the employment of young people. Young people and the employers are entitled to know that their jobs and employing rights are secure. The youth employment bill will provide this certainty by permanently exempting junior rates from the age discrimination requirements of the Workplace Relations Act. I commend the bill to the House and present the explanatory memorandum.

talk.start.para: —There is no need for me, as is the normal practice, to call for the adjournment of the debate because, according to the resolution before the House, the debate is adjourned and the resumption of the debate will be made an order of the day for the next sitting.

—Before I proceed to put the question that the House do now adjourn, I intend to extend to the member for Calwell some indulgence because he has indicated there is a matter of some personal urgency that he wishes to bring to the attention of the House.

—This will not take long, and I have been waiting since 3 o'clock. In today's Sydney Morning Herald and Melbourne Age there is a story about me which makes a number of serious and false allegations. This story is a malicious smear on me. It is an attempt to destroy my parliamentary reputation and especially my many years of work in the areas of immigration and multiculturalism. I completely deny the allegations in these two newspapers. In particular, the claim that, `On one occasion it is understood that around $20,000 in cash was handed to Dr Theophanous,' is an outrageous lie which is intended to create the maximum public damage to me.

speech.para: Ever since the decision in 1993 to allow the Chinese students and their dependants to stay in Australia, I have been subjected to continuing false attacks. Two investigations have cleared me. Today's newspaper story is part of a further systematic and scurrilous attack on me.

However, there are many issues involved in this latest matter. Some of these issues will be of grave concern to members of this House when they are released. They are issues that go to the very heart of the question as to whether members of parliament can confidentially serve their constituents, especially people facing a crisis and needing our help.

In conclusion, I repeat again that I am innocent of these alleged misdeeds. However, I have been advised by my lawyers to make no more comment until further events unfold. In the meantime, I will continue to perform my parliamentary duties albeit under difficult circumstances.

debate.para: The following notices were given:
Mr Speaker to present a bill for an act to provide for the establishment and management of the Australian Parliamentary Service, and for other purposes.
Mrs Crosio to move:
That the House:

(1) notes with concern that the Environmental Impact Study (EIS) of the Badgerys Creek Airport proposal does not contain an examination of the extent to which a very fast train link between Sydney and Canberra—and eventually from Canberra to Melbourne— would reduce domestic air traffic at Sydney's Kingsford-Smith Airport and therefore negate the need to make an immediate decision on building a second international airport in the Sydney basin;

(2) recognises that building a 24-hour international airport at Badgerys Creek will attract an estimated 77 000 extra daily vehicle movements on western Sydney's already congested roads and the disastrous economic, social and environmental problems that such a traffic explosion would cause;

(3) notes with concern that the EIS auditor, the Snowy Mountains Engineering Corporation (SMEC), has revealed that a cost-benefit analysis of the Badgerys Creek Airport proposal does not support the construction of an airport at this site;
(4) acknowledges that building a 24-hour international airport at Badgerys Creek will endanger the Greater Blue Mountains area being declared a World Heritage site; and
(5) recognises that 10 of the 11 councils that will be affected by the proposed Badgerys Creek airport and both the NSW State Government and Opposition are against the airport's development.
Mr Price to move:
That the House:
(1) notes with concern the Government's apparent lack of concern regarding the economic, social and environmental impacts of the proposed development of a 24-hour airport at Badgerys Creek;

(2) recognises that the residents of Mount Druitt, Rooty Hill, Whalan, Tregear, Emerton, Dharruk, Hebersham, Oxley Park, St Clair, St Marys, Plumpton, Doonside, Minchinbury, Shalvey, Willmot, Bidwell, Blackett, Hassall Grove, Glendenning, Marsden Park, Lethbridge Park, Colyton, Erskine Park, Eastern Creek and Blacktown will be adversely affected by the construction of the airport;
(3) notes that the State Government, State Opposition and 10 Western Sydney Councils are opposed to the construction of an airport on this site;
(4) acknowledges that alternative sites for an airport have not been fully investigated;
(5) acknowledges that alternative options for a more efficient use of existing Sydney airports have not been fully investigated;
(6) acknowledges that the draft Environmental Impact Study (EIS) is fundamentally flawed in regards to its terms of reference and its outcomes;
(7) recognises that the full EIS has not been an open and transparent process; and
(8) regrets the failure of the Government to release the final EIS.
Mrs Irwin to move:
That the House:

(1) notes that during the 1996 election campaign, the Government promised the people of Western Sydney an open, transparent and accountable process in determining the future for the Badgerys Creek airport site;

(2) notes with concern that the release of the final Environmental Impact Study (EIS) of the Badgerys Creek airport has been continually delayed by the Government, despite its stated intentions to release it, in clear breach of their election promises;

(3) acknowledges that the residents of Ashcroft, Bonnyrigg, Busby, Cabramatta, Cabramatta West, Canley Heights, Canley Vale, Cartwright, Edensor Park, Green Valley, Heckenberg, Hinchinbrook, Lansvale, Liverpool, Miller, Mt Pritchard, Sadleir, St Johns Park, Warwick Farm and Wakely have the right to be fully informed of the impact of the construction of a 24-hour international airport at Badgerys Creek;
(4) recognises that 10 Western Sydney councils, the State Government and the State Opposition are opposed to the construction of the Badgerys Creek airport;

(5) acknowledges the growing concern by the people of Western Sydney about the potential impact of the airport and their falling confi dence levels in the EIS process and the manner in which the Government is handling the development of Sydney's second airport; and

(6) recognises that the Government has failed to examine in detail alternative proposals to Badgerys Creek for the second airport's location and alternative proposals for more efficient use of existing airport infrastructure in Sydney.
Mr Laurie Ferguson to move:
That the House:

(1) recognises that building a 24-hour international airport at Badgerys Creek will unfairly shift many of the environmental and social problems currently facing the residents living in the vicinity of Sydney's Kingsford-Smith Airport on to the residents of western Sydney;

(2) notes that by the time an international airport built at Badgerys Creek is fully operative, the population in Sydney's greater west that will surround the development and be affected by its operations will have reached close to 2 million;

(3) notes the already high levels of air pollution endured by the people of western Sydney and the increasing rates of respiratory illness suffered by the area's population and that a 24-hour international airport at Badgerys Creek would only exacerbate the problem; and
(4) questions the suggested job growth figures that will eventuate following the development of an airport at Badgerys Creek.
Mr Mossfield to move:
That the House:
(1) notes the ongoing opposition by local residents to the building of an airport at Badgerys Creek by many Western Sydney MPs including Government and Opposition parties and local government groups;
(2) notes that opposition to the proposed airport was made a key issue in most Western Sydney electorates by all party candidates during the last federal election;

(3) recognises that the serious and justifiable concerns expressed by residents of inner Sydney to the noise and pollution effects caused by Kingsford-Smith Airport cannot be solved by simply moving the whole problem out to and onto Western Sydney residents;
(4) acknowledges that both the NSW Carr Government and the Chikarovski Opposition oppose the building of an airport at Badgerys Creek;

(5) challenges the claim of massive job creation by any such building of Badgerys Creek and declares that existing employees would merely transfer their worksite from Kingsford-Smith to Badgerys Creek; and
(6) calls on the Government to quickly abandon the Badgerys Creek airport proposal and place any new second airport outside the Sydney basin.
Mr McGauran to present a bill for an act to amend the Broadcasting Services Act 1992, and for other purposes.
Mr Reith to move:
That standing order 399 be suspended for the remainder of this period of sittings, except when a motion is moved pursuant to the standing order by a Minister.

business.start.para: Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER(Mr Nehl) took the chair at 9.40 a.m.

talk.start.para: —Page 1 of yesterday's Sydney Morning Herald , under the banner headline `The "great Australian dream" Mark 2 up for grabs', championed the Howard government's announcement that the $16 billion sell-off of Telstra `would see a new generation fulfilling the new "great Australian dream" of owning shares'. Further, the Sydney Morning Herald reported:

speech.para: Telstra shares may be on the shopping list of most leading stockbrokers, but they say there are many other shares worth considering before spending $5,000 or $10,000 on the phone giant.

I ask: how many battlers have a spare $5,000 or $10,000? When I last spoke in the Main Committee about the first one-third sale of Telstra, on 26 November 1998, I highlighted the fact that the float price was undervalued by 50 per cent. In other words, we, the taxpayers and the owners of Telstra, were the victims of daylight robbery by the Howard government's first float.

Most galling of all, the taxpayers and the owners of Telstra are going to be robbed again with the latest 16 per cent sell-off. Day after day I have had to suffer the Prime Minister and the Treasurer seducing the Australian people with the line about how wonderful it will be that more and more mums and dads can own shares in this great, profitable national asset. But I ask: at what cost? The people of Australia already own two-thirds of Telstra—and it should be 100 per cent. But worse, 35 per cent of Telstra can be foreign owned.

What we have here is a typical coalition government bribe which appeals to the rich and the greedy. Once again the Howard government is robbing the poor to reward those in our society who are already better off, so that they can feel warm and cosy as the value of their Telstra share portfolio blossoms. Those who already own Telstra shares can also look forward to a better deal if they buy more shares. This is disgraceful.

With the first one-third sell-off, we witnessed massive job losses and a marked reduction in services. It is obvious that this scenario will continue with the latest sell-off. Once again, the public interest has been massively kicked in the guts. If the public think that out of this they will be able to get their telephones installed or serviced quicker, they had better think again. After all, we know that the shareholders will demand profits, and Telstra management will make sure that the value of the shares increases at the expense of services to the Australian people.

It is outrageous to read in the Sydney Morning Herald that the brokers and merchant bankers will be the biggest winners in this latest float. The Sydney Morning Herald estimates that they stand to reap an estimated $240 million in fees. This is appalling. The tragedy in all of this is that the Howard government does not intend to stop here. The government has made it quite clear that it wants to fully privatise Telstra. Sadly, once this great asset is sold it can never be bought back by the legitimate owners—the Australian public.

talk.start.para: —I have tried three times to give this three-minute speech but, unfortunately, due to the attitude of those opposite, the limited time available to members has been reduced in the last couple of weeks. I would like to raise the issue of youth and youth homelessness and the whole issue of young people in the community. In my electorate of Longman, a couple of weeks ago the local paper put out a headline `Youth in despair'. I think it is those sorts of headlines which really stereotype people's opinions of young people which are quite wrong. The fact is that the majority of young people in the electorate of Longman, whether they be on Bribie Island, at Caboolture, Deception Bay, Maleny or Beerwah, are high achievers. They are people who are representing their country and their state in sport; they do very well in school; they participate in debates.

speech.para: But there is a small group of people who, for whatever reason—through family breakdown or through some other form of disadvantage—have found themselves falling through the cracks of society. I am very pleased that the government, through its initiatives yesterday and also through an earlier announcement this week, is going to introduce two more JPET programs, which address these very needs, into the electorate of Longman.

In Deception Bay, which is an area of depression with high unemployment, where young people certainly need greater assistance, the youth workers of that district are going to be funded by this government for an additional 50 places for young people who are at risk—helping them to get the education they need, the services they need, the homes they need and the love and the support which will enable them to become fuller members of our society.

A number of young people come to Caboolture and Morayfield, which are areas on the northern rail line. They are not locals; they are basically dumped there. When they arrive, they get off the train wondering where they are going to go. The local Salvation Army will now be providing 100 places—funded through the JPET program—to people in greatest need.

These are responsible policies of this government which acknowledge that not everybody is being well served by their family, by the community, by government and by the schooling system. That is why these innovative and extended programs are important. I commend not only the government for doing this but also those who provide the services on the ground. This initiative will ensure that young people get not only social and economic sustenance but also a feeling of wellbeing that the rest of us take for granted—on both sides of the House. These two initiatives will go a long way to addressing that small group of people—the youth at risk—in the Longman electorate.

I reiterate that the overwhelming majority of young people throughout the Longman electorate are in fact high achievers who are doing very well. They have good prospects and do us all proud. The media should not attack young people by saying, `Youth in despair'; they should champion those who are doing such a very good job in our society.

talk.start.para: —I rise to congratulate the Christian Brethren Assemblies of Tasmania on the opening of their new recreation stadium at Camp Clayton Camping and Convention Centre. Situated at the coastal end of the beautiful Forth Valley—my home valley—Camp Clayton offers a comprehensive program of holiday activities for young people, leadership courses for over 100 volunteer young people every year, the hosting of special needs groups, the provision of retreats and family based ministry, and structured camp activities for over 50 Tasmanian schools.

speech.para: Started in 1950, Camp Clayton is fully booked all year round and has established a state-wide reputation for providing quality accommodation and programs. There is something very special about Camp Clayton, and I sought to isolate this quality when I had the privilege of opening the new stadium last Friday. I highlighted four Ps in my endeavours.

P for place. Camp Clayton is situated at Turners Beach on 26 hectares, bounded by Bass Strait and incorporating prime agricultural land. Valued at over $3.5 million, it can accommodate 250 campers at any time in unsurpassed natural and landscaped surroundings. Its units are of excellent quality and its recreational facilities are first class. Although this is very important, this does not make Camp Clayton special.
P for programs. I have highlighted the extensive programs above, and these respond to a variety of needs, both community and personal. But these alone do not make Camp Clayton special.

P for people. Now this is getting closer to my search. Camp Clayton is the result of countless thousands of dollars of donated materials and thousands of hours of volunteer labour since 1950—the generous donation of time by camp leaders, youth workers and the board of management. This generosity of people leads me to the complementary key factor defining Camp Clayton.

P for purpose. This is the essential meaning to Camp Clayton—the provision of programs to young people in a secure, safe, innovative environment, based on the Christian value of loving, nurturing and caring for our young people. Camp Clayton personifies this value in every sense—from the physical environment to its extensive person-oriented programs. Camp Clayton incorporates its community in its programs and presence in every sense of the word.

I was very proud to open the new stadium valued at something like $800,000, yet in a sense I was a little embarrassed. You see, Camp Clayton does not use government funds or grants. Wonderfully, it is a great example of self-help based on the principle that in self-help there is genuine ownership, fellowship and a sense of belonging. Indeed, self-help is a purpose in itself.

On behalf of the people of Tasmania, and my region in particular, I wish to congratulate all those involved with Camp Clayton and to thank them for their excellent ministry. I know all members in this chamber would be proud to have such a total concept as Camp Clayton in their electorate. I certainly am. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: —In my electorate of Gilmore, there are many people whose kidneys are in trouble. A number of these people are on dialysis, whether it be home or hospital based treatment. The nearest dialysis facility is at Wollongong—an hour's journey to the north. For those who take the ambulance to Wollongong hospital, it is a very long day. They start off at about 10 o'clock in the morning, and they are often not home until 1 or 2 o'clock the next morning. A long day indeed when you are already not feeling well, but made even more intrusive by the fact that the trip is made three times a week, each week. They dare not miss a trip: miss three trips and you are dead; it is that serious.

speech.para: This is an exhausting process that prolongs life but adds no quality to it. Upon hearing of the plight of these people, our local community sprang into action. Although they did not know the people or the machinery that they were going to fund, our local Lions clubs joined together to stage an enormous appeal. Others gained agreement from the health authorities to assist in the design and fit-out of a dialysis ward in the Shoalhaven area. Many organisations and individuals banded together with the expertise and organisational skills of the local Lions clubs. The target was set at a seemingly impossible $500,000 and the fundraising began.

Just about everybody in my electorate went to an event of some sort, bought raffle tickets, sold raffle tickets or made donations, cakes or fools of themselves just to help raise money for the dialysis ward. Some groups had golf days, race days, dances, fetes and festivals. Other groups and businesses challenged one another to meet or better their fundraising efforts. Some people got their hair cut, others cut their pocket money, and on and on it went, seemingly forever without let-up.

When walking the streets it became difficult to dodge those avid dialysis dollar demands. We were not safe in our homes either. The local radio personality, Barry Mac, urged us to greater effort and made the journey more pleasant by providing positive messages and regular updates on the total sum raised so far. He also MCed events, and his radio station, 2ST, allowed him to run a couple of his famous Saturday night rock-and-roll segments at local clubs where his entertainment was greatly appreciated. Franz Mairinger, Lions Council Chairman, and his band of merry Lions did not limit their fundraising efforts to the local area. They went right to the top and petitioned Lions International to help, which they did very generously. The federal government also assisted with a donation of $100,000.

So our community raised the $500,000 in less than 12 months. The new ward should be operational in the next couple of weeks. Our dialysis patients will then have less travelling time added to their day and, when they are finished the treatment, they will be able to go straight home instead of having to wait for everyone else to be finished as well. It is so heartening when this sort of joint effort demonstrates the word `unity' in the word `community'. The people of my electorate know how to look after one another, and that is why Gilmore is such a great place to be.

talk.start.para: —I rise to speak on an issue of vital importance to not only my electorate of Oxley but also neighbouring electorates. This issue, the appalling condition of the Ipswich motorway, is one which I have brought to the attention of the House previously. The motorway is now a national disgrace. It is part of the national highway system and is the main arterial road available for people travelling from Brisbane to Ipswich and further on to Toowoomba, in the seat of Groom, and to Warwick, in the seat of Blair.

speech.para: In 1997, the Queensland state government conducted a safety audit of the motorway and found that the road system was in desperate need of safety repairs to the tune of $42 million. To date, only $6 million has been spent with $36 million still required. These repairs are not for beautification or for political point scoring; these repairs are required to correct serious safety problems with the Ipswich motorway, in particular the sections between Redbank and Wacol.

About 75,000 vehicles a day use the motorway and, at peak times, it may as well be a car park with average speeds estimated at around 19 kilometres per hour. At other times, when the speed limit of 100 kilometres per hour is reached, the road becomes a death trap. It has claimed many lives and has caused many accidents. It affects not only the constituents of Oxley but all travellers who use this road system—who are, as I said earlier, many. It affects many electorates, the economic growth of the region and, in the end, all of Queensland. Regardless of the political divide between electorates, it is imperative that Queensland receive the funding it needs to carry out urgent road safety repairs and maintenance.

I would like to join the member for Groom, Ian Macfarlane, and the member for Blair, Cameron Thompson, in their calls for the federal government to support the provision of funds needed in this region. I also support the statement by the member for Blair in this House on 17 February this year when he said:
My agenda . . . is the issue of roads . . . I want to look at what is being done to appropriate money to make sure those roads are at the highest possible standard.

Not a day goes by without government members from both the Liberal and National parties saying that they care about rural and regional Australia, and that only they understand the needs of rural and regional Australia. Here is your opportunity to prove it.

I can no longer tolerate picking up my local paper and reading of the carnage on our main road system through this region. I also know that many accidents are not reported because of their frequency. When will the government decide that it is time to act? Will it be when a bus has a head-on with a family on its way home from an evening out? Or will it be when a car-load of tourists careers off this inadequate highway into a minibus full of holiday-makers? How many lives must be lost before the imperative for the repair of this road is greater than the imperative for penny-pinching? This government's allocation of $25 million for the whole state of Queensland represents exactly what they think of rural and regional Australia: very little. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: —This is not the first time I have raised the issue of biotechnology and the government's efforts to begin to tackle the implications of the great strides being made both here and overseas in biotechnology engineering and commercialisation. It is an area of enormous opportunity, an area where our lives will be changed in a way that we cannot even forecast right now. But there are some implications and considerations our country needs to address surrounding the impact of genetic manipulation, ownership of gene technology—in particular, who should own the intellectual property associated with gene technology—and the potential for genetic pollution.

speech.para: I was terrified to read in the US that Harvard University has secured patent ownership over not only the genetic technology used to develop a cancer-susceptible mouse—the `oncomouse'—but also the mouse itself. So they own the technology and the mammal. After having secured that patent ownership in the US, they then thought `We'll head north' and they went up to Canada. Thankfully, the Canadian Federal Court has rejected the claim of ownership over the mammal. In his decision, Judge Marc Nadon stated:
They have created a method to inject eggs with a myc gene but they have not invented the mouse.

The thing that concerns me about this is the aggressive pursuit of intellectual property ownership as evidenced in the case with Harvard University. This is just the tip of the iceberg. At the end of the day, who is going to decide when and under what terms genetically enhanced organisms will be released and made available? What price will we pay if other nations or other multinationals who are not friendly to our interests own those patents and decide when we can have access to them? That potential impact on our nation would be quite significant. That is only one area.

Another area relates to the testing of genetically enhanced organisms. We have lamented, over many generations, our efforts to modify the environment with the introduction of cane toads and rabbits. Now there is the prospect of having genetically enhanced organisms released. That of itself should not terrify us, as long as we do our homework first. In the next decade there may well be a proposition before this parliament to create a biosphere-controlled environment where we can test some of these organisms before we release them into the environment.

One side of politics will be ready to address those challenges: the coalition. In the budget, there has already been funding earmarked for a comprehensive new biotechnology strategy. We have heard about the development of the office of gene technology regulator, and funding has been made available for that. Again, the coalition is at the front end of these important policy issues. Unlike the opposition, this government recognises the major technological advances that have been made. But, once again, where is Labor? AWOL—absent without leadership on this important issue. We are looking to the coalition to again do what is needed for the country. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: —Order! In accordance with standing order 275A the time for members' statements has concluded.

subdebate.1.para: Debate resumed from 3 June, on motion by Mr Vaile:
That the bill be now read a second time.

talk.start.para: —The Damage by Aircraft Bill 1999 seeks to improve compensation arrangements for third parties on the ground who suffer death, personal injury or property damage as a consequence of an air accident. As the shadow minister and previous opposition members who have spoken on this bill have already indicated, the Labor Party supports the government in these efforts. This bill makes a pleasant change from the usual air transport legislation which this government develops and puts forward, and which is usually unclear, inept, surrounded by secrecy and generally mismanaged.

speech.para: The current compensation arrangements for third parties affected by air accidents are entirely inadequate and need revision. Compensation for third parties on the ground in the case of an air crash in Australia is currently determined by our being a signatory to the Rome convention of 1952, the details of which are given force of law by the Civil Aviation (Damage by Aircraft) Act 1958.

The Rome convention was developed to harmonise compensation payments between countries when international aircraft cause damage to parties on the ground. However, a number of holes exist in the convention, and subsequently in the act as it currently stands. While attempting to bring harmony to international compensation arrangements, the Rome convention actually falls far from it. Only 38 countries are party to it and only seven of the signatory countries are licensed to operate in Australia at any one time. Countries that are not signatories to the convention include the United States, Japan, China, Thailand, Malaysia, Indonesia and the United Kingdom. Indeed, the majority of international carriers that operate in Australia are not covered by the convention.
